issueDTO.title: Help us migrate & improve 🍉 documentation
issueDTO.description:
Hey,

I'd like to migrate WatermelonDB docs from `mdbook` to Docusaurus, a de facto standard in the React/React Native community for project websites. With that, I'd also like documentation to feature an actual API reference, and not just guides. I hope that will help 🍉 users a lot.

But with many other maintenance responsibilities on my mind, I'd like help from the community with this. Can you help?
comments:
I can help but would probably just need some direction since I've never done this before!

Would be nice if there were more comprehensive tutorials & examples that way there'll probably be less issues opened where people ask how to do things (myself included haha).  A couple things that I have found myself struggling / unable to really figure out personally would be:

- sync (steep learning curve and ran into a lot of roadblocks with implementing but might be due to lack of experience on my end)
- writer methods (nothing seemed to happen)
- cascade deletions on related tables without having to manually do so

A troubleshooting page of common problems (like https://github.com/Nozbe/WatermelonDB/pull/615) and a FAQ (dealing with the sync when offline, possibility of multiple relations to the same table, expo related questions, etc) would be useful as well. Also, there's someone with a PR open that is trying to add info to the observables section: https://github.com/Nozbe/WatermelonDB/pull/1447 which might be good as well

I'll try to put together an example project that does the full front and backend sync if I can get some free time haha. It would be nice if people could submit their own example projects too and that way there could be a couple different kinds of examples (simple & complex) 


Also the demo is down: https://github.com/Nozbe/WatermelonDB/issues/1415#issue-1420236273

---
Some other things I noticed were that the migrations page is under the Advanced section but says:
> Without migrations, if a user of your app upgrades from one version to another, their local database will be cleared at launch, and they will lose all their data.
> ?????? Always use migrations!

If it is essential, I think it should be moved up closer to setup. My idea for sections with the current information would be something like:

- About (1.1)
   - All the sections could probably be split into separate pages for readability and easier navigation
- Setup (2.1 - 2.4 + 3.1)
- Usage (2.5 -2.9)
- Sync (its own section)
- Troubleshooting
- FAQ
- The rest of the current sections seem good as is (maybe the LokiJS & web implementation should get their own section but I don't use it so I'm not quite sure)

Let me know what you think!

---
Also, not sure if there are any other maintainers (with privileges to merge in PRs & close issues) on the repo? As far as I could tell, it's just you? Not sure if this is an option for 🍉 since it's a Nozbe repo but having more maintainers would probably help. I could probably put in a PR at https://github.com/pickhardt/maintainers-wanted if you were looking for active maintainers or just pin an issue to recruit some.

I want to help too, do you have anything in mind related to how it should be structured in the repo?

The current setup has the docs-master/ with the .md files and the generated docs/ folder.

Can it be changed to something like the structure found in the [react-native-navigation](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/tree/master/website) repo, it features the API reference you mentioned or even [react-native-website](https://github.com/facebook/react-native-website)

Both of these examples also have versioning, is that something useful here?

@ErickLuizA Yes, I'd like to change the structure a bit, it seems to confuse a lot of people that docs-master/ is the current version of docs that matches code on master, while `docs/` matches the latest published version.

Regarding versioning, it's a nice to have, but not super important to me. I think we can start with a simple docusaurus setup, then add API reference, and then maybe think about how to ship versioned docs.

We have this! @ErickLuizA thank you for your contribution.

The new website will be shipped alongside 0.26.0 release, for now you can view it locally like so:

```
cd docs-website
yarn
cd ..
yarn docs:dev  # opens in browser
```

@KrisLau Your help would be definitely appreciated.

One thing you could start with if you're unsure about drafting new articles is just cleaning up the existing docs:

- Splitting large guide articles into smaller ones
- Throughout the docs, adding types to examples would be helpful. Things have changed since 2018, and I think we can now assume that most people use TypeScript/Flow, and whoever doesn't can just ignore them
- Changing navigation to be closer to your suggestion seems like a good idea
@radex Will do, I'll try to get to it as soon as I get some free time!

> About the generate docs from source code, there are some solutions, I tested the [jsdoc-to-mdx](https://github.com/naver/jsdoc-to-mdx), it appears to work, although I kind of just put some text and see if it outputs something, if you wanna check it out, it's in this [branch](https://github.com/ErickLuizA/WatermelonDB/tree/migrate-docs-docusaurus-jsdoc), btw, for some reason, to work I need to put the comment in the .js and d.ts to work 🤔

> There is [this gist](https://gist.github.com/slorber/0bf8c8c8001505f0f99a062ac55bf442) from the maintainer of docusaurus, but I was not able to make it run, there is also https://github.com/facebook/docusaurus/issues/3413, but it's for typescript.

@ErickLuizA Can you help out with that? In general, JSDoc or something similar to annotate symbols with text seems good. JSDoc has the advantage that is has been around for a very long time, so even if one breaks, there's always going to be some tool to extract it and format it somehow.

It would be great not to have to duplicate types and just take function signatures automatically, and I think I've seen somewhere one-off scripts to help with that for Flow, but Flow just isn't that popular anymore, so it might be hard to maintain. Typedoc on the other hand looks interesting (though I don't really like how it formats the output), but I'm not sure it's a good idea to keep the main in-code documentation not in the main code but in the d.ts files.

So I think it would be great to start with a working demo of jsdoc-to-mdx, and then iterate from there
I added some JSDoc comments to Database, Collection, etc. cc @ErickLuizA
Also to Model, Schema, sync

I have not been able to open a PR with the API Reference because I didn't find a way to make jsdoc-to-mdx work properly
I don't know why, but it has some problems with flow or the .d.ts files or both.

I will try to work on another solution, maybe with [jsdoc-to-markdown](https://github.com/jsdoc2md/jsdoc-to-markdown), it does not work out of the box with docusaurus but it's more popular, I will see if it can work.
I will help.
@lucaswitch Much appreciated, do you need guidance as for where to start?
I added JSDoc to Query class as well
@radex Restructured and split up long sections here: https://github.com/Nozbe/WatermelonDB/pull/1535. Let me know what you think and sorry it took so long to get to it!
@KrisLau Nice, appreciated. A few nitpicks and the README, and we'll get that merged.

Hi, would love to help if still possible!

I don't know if that's the appropriate place to say this but I just tried the lib for the first time and I must say that getting a new app to work correctly with 🍉 following the documentation was a pain.
Maybe that's just me but I really struggled to find informations about `DatabaseProvider`, `withDatabase` and even the examples in the repo didn't help.

Anyway, let me know if I can contribute!
@adblanc You can!
@radex I was busy, is there any new docs job left to do?

@lucaswitch Some suggestions:

- Add TypeScript types to examples in the docs
- Add docs to whatever you feel like is missing/confusing currently
- Help develop API docs by looking into JSDoc to mdx converter that @ErickLuizA started work on https://github.com/Nozbe/WatermelonDB/issues/1481#issuecomment-1428936096
- Help develop API docs by filling in missing comments above classes and methods throughout the codebase. You can look at Database, Model, Query to see some of the work I've already done. But other things, such as explaining constructor options to SQLiteAdapter/LokiJSAdapter, decorators, Sync are not yet documented in this way.
I'm starting on the task "Add TypeScript types to examples in the docs" not quite done yet.

@radex 
Hello everyone, I'm studying React Native and Watermelon and would also like to help with project documentation. Do you have any tips on where to start?

I think It might be a good idea to write a way to test with jest and WatermelonDB. I put a memo under [my blog](https://medium.com/@naoyam_m/a-way-to-test-with-watermelondb-28ae275957bc). If it is ok to add, I will do that!

issueDTO.title: FFI Iterator
issueDTO.description:
Iterating across the FFI boundary is extremely slow, so it was initially determined to not be included. However, it may be necessary for some coreth API functionality (as well as being generally helpful for testing). This could still be implemented relatively simply by amortizing the FFI calls to batch the key-value pairs to relatively few calls. This will still require some clever memory management to avoid copying too much data (idea: allocate a pool in Go?) and to enable 2D arrays in C to be translated into slices of slices in Go. Additionally, freeing the iterator may be difficult if using a literal Rust iterator. 

At minimum, this must (in ethhash):
- Provide an iterator for accounts (values associated with keys of length 32)
- Given an account hash (length 32), iterate through all storage values associated with this account (all values of length 64 with keys prefixed with the account hash)
comments: @alarso16 do we still need this?

Yes we do! In coreth, we will be returning errors on some APIs until we add this (see ava-labs/coreth#1059). The way these APIs are implemented can be different than the way they are currently, for Firewood specifically. For example, maybe using the ChangeProof api with slightly changed semantics might work well.

repository.description: Compaction-Less Database Optimized for Efficiently Storing Recent Merkleized Blockchain State
repository.name: firewood

summary.main: Implement an FFI iterator to iterate across the FFI boundary, allowing for efficient iteration across account storage values and enabling testing and coreth API functionality
summary.validationOrRequirement: must provide an iterator for accounts, iterate through storage values associated with an account hash, and handle errors on some APIs in coreth
summary.attemptedFixes: batching key-value pairs to reduce FFI calls, allocating a pool in Go for memory management, translating 2D arrays in C to slices of slices in Go
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to coreth API functionality and testing, and requires clever memory management to avoid data copying. Additionally, freeing the iterator may be difficult if using a literal Rust iterator.

issueDTO.title: FlowItemLike["beforeBack"] is marked as required in TypeScript - probably should not
issueDTO.description:
### Check existing issues

- [x] I have [checked for existing issues](https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/issues) to avoid duplicates

### Actual Behavior

The FlowItemLike marks `beforeBack` as a required property, but as per its description it should be optional.

https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/blob/618973fecf357e1f5a8e51f833efdde5099751eb/packages/calcite-components/src/components/flow/interfaces.ts#L110

Consider marking the property as typescript-optional in FlowItem by adding `?`:
https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/blob/618973fecf357e1f5a8e51f833efdde5099751eb/packages/calcite-components/src/components/flow-item/flow-item.tsx#L68-L69

```diff
- @property() beforeBack: () => Promise<void>; 
+ @property() beforeBack?: () => Promise<void>; 
```


Alternatively, you can modify the TypeScript type as follows:
```sh
export type FlowItemLike = Pick<HTMLCalciteFlowItemElement, "menuOpen" | "setFocus" | "showBackButton" | "selected"> &
  Partial<
    Pick<
      HTMLCalciteFlowItemElement,
      "beforeBack"
    >
  >;
```

### Expected Behavior

beforeBack is marked as optional in the types

### Reproduction Sample

np

### Reproduction Steps

Open https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/blob/618973fecf357e1f5a8e51f833efdde5099751eb/packages/calcite-components/src/components/flow/interfaces.ts#L110 in the IDE

See that temporary this code snippet in that file will error because the `beforeBack` is marked as required:

```ts
const test:FlowItemLike = {
  menuOpen: false,
  setFocus: () => Promise.resolve(),
  showBackButton: false,
  selected: false,
}
```

### Reproduction Version

3.3.0

### Relevant Info

_No response_

### Regression?

_No response_

### Priority impact

impact - p3 - not time sensitive

### Impact

_No response_

### Calcite package

- [x] @esri/calcite-components
- [ ] @esri/calcite-components-react
- [ ] @esri/calcite-design-tokens
- [ ] @esri/calcite-ui-icons
- [ ] @esri/eslint-plugin-calcite-components

### Esri team

ArcGIS Maps SDK for JavaScript
comments: cc @AdelheidF
cc @driskull

issueDTO.title: SingleSignOn (OAuth)
issueDTO.description:
My docker containers are usually in internal networks with no ports exposed. I am accessing all my services via reverse proxy that is secured via Authentik. 

In (future) future releases it would be nice to add authentication using Proxy/OAuth. 

Somehow it seems to be possible to implement OAuth with FastAPI.
comments:
There are a few oauth2 use cases to think about:
1. What happens when an existing user logs in with an oauth2 provider? Are they matched by email and asked to verify the login?
2. What happens when a new user logs in via oauth2? Should we create a new account? There isn't a user registration flow yet.
3. What if a user changes their email address then logs in with an oauth2 provider with the old address? The lookup wouldn't find the user any longer so it would probably go to the new user flow.

issueDTO.title: Ability to pin a manual trigger in the navbar
issueDTO.description: # Desired Behavior We want users to be able to pin a workflow manual trigger in the navbar. Add the "Pinned in Navbar" setting on the workflow manual trigger. The menu on the left displays the setting associated with this parameter. Also update the order of the fields as follow: https://www.figma.com/design/xt8O9mFeLl46C5InWwoMrN/Twenty?node-id=45225-494500&t=aUXwJrllQjmToU2m-11
comments:
To do that:
- add isPinned to the workflow trigger settings, update `getManualTriggerDefaultSettings`

issueDTO.title: c2pa.metadata Assertion support
issueDTO.description:
2.2 moves the EXIF and IPTC assertions into the [c2pa.metadata assertion](https://spec.c2pa.org/specifications/specifications/2.2/specs/C2PA_Specification.html#_metadata). We need to create test cases for these data types and then update our other tools to look for metadata in this assertion.

 There's a [section](https://spec.c2pa.org/specifications/specifications/2.2/specs/C2PA_Specification.html#metadata_annex) that details all the data that is valid for a Metadata assertion. In theory we need to validate that only those fields are present. 

I'd set the highest priority on making sure we know how to generate a subset of this data and read it back in a valid form.

First we need to create test cases and then we need to do the proper validations.

2.2 requires validation of c2pa.metdata assertions.  This task is to support those validations 

Somewhere down the road we may want to test this by automatically moving metadata from XMP into one of these assertions. But we would need to be very selective, so I'm not sure about that.
comments: This also needs to be validated and exposed at the top level API.
:white_check_mark: Jira issue https://jira.corp.adobe.com/browse/CAI-8974 is successfully created for this GitHub issue.

repository.description: Rust SDK for the core C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity) specification
repository.name: c2pa-rs

summary.main: Support c2pa.metadata assertion by creating test cases and validating it according to the 2.2 specification
summary.validationOrRequirement: Validate that only the fields present in the metadata annex are present, and generate a subset of this data and read it back in a valid form
summary.attemptedFixes: Creating test cases and doing proper validations
summary.otherNotes: This issue is related to the 2.2 specification, specifically the metadata assertion section. It requires validation of c2pa.metadata assertions and creation of test cases.

issueDTO.title: Cmd+click to linkify file in terminal doesn't work when there are whitespace or certain separators in the filename
issueDTO.description: ### Check for existing issues - [X] Completed ### Describe the bug / provide steps to reproduce it For example, these 3 filenames won't work: * 'test file 1.txt' * test???2.txt * test???3.txt ### Environment Zed: v0.137.2 (Zed Preview) OS: macOS 14.4.1 Memory: 16 GiB Architecture: aarch64 ### If applicable, add mockups / screenshots to help explain present your vision of the feature _No response_ ### If applicable, attach your `~/Library/Logs/Zed/Zed.log` file to this issue. _No response_
comments: See https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/issues/8256#issuecomment-1960944540 for a similar bug the explanation and https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/pull/8321 and https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/pull/2899 for the PR example.

Hi @SomeoneToIgnore 

I am able to reproduce the bug in the project and would like to contribute a fix. 

'test file 1.txt'
test???2.txt
test???3.txt

In above case adding ???and ??? are straight-forward. 

Incase of whitespaces, if we modified the regex to add (\s), it will pick up the whole line in regex, instead of file

`drwxr-xr-x   11 test  test     352 Jun  7 2o:40 test test.txt`

Can you help in proceeding in right direction?

Not sure the issue could be solved by just accepting more spaces for the string.
We seem to need to start supporting some ways of finding `'`-quoted strings, which seems conditional already, making regex usage harder?

There are few hacks around the `[]` matching already:
https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/blob/dcb4f73540fb8ab4c942a50148e8956282383bc3/crates/terminal/src/terminal.rs#L827
so we might do the following:
* extract the entire "find all path-like things" into a separate method/function, so we can test it somehow + add a few tests

If we start to ingrain more logic, we'd better be sure to test its correctness.

* after tests for all desired cases are written, it's easier to check multiple approaches.
I do not see anything good in particular, but overall it does not seem feasible to include that into `word_regex` ?????instead, I'd have another regex or logic to match texts between two `'` quotes ??? note that the quotes can be nested (e.g. due to escaping `'my very weird file with\' symbol inside.bat'`, so not sure that regex is a good solution here.

* On top of that, we might want to deduplicate multiple matches, if one contains another.

Same issue when using a command line tool like jest, tsc or knip

Zed does not detect the path when I cmd+hover the path

clicking file protocol paths aren't working for me in Zed Dev 0.154.0, e.g. clicking any of these does nothing:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/811cedb0-4693-494e-9792-fafb966293c4)

Oddly enough they highlight on hover, so seems they are recognized as links but then nothing happens when you click.
I went ahead and put together a prototype to facilitate design/discussion/testing here: https://github.com/davewa/zed/tree/terminal-hyperlinks.

Thank you for the prototype, much simpler to discuss things based on this.

I see a few things worth highlighting:

* Seems that we might want to unite custom regexes with the existing one: `[DEFAULT_REGEX]` or something in the settings.
One gotcha is that the default regex needs some `[path] -> path` special handling, but we hardcode that regex anyway hence when matching, can do extra checks for the default one.

* Despite all the docs, it's totally unclear why do those regex settings exist: we might want to emphasize that this path capturing is for `cmd+click` and whatever matched will be checked for existence before opening (so, a "bad" regex capture is not guaranteed to be opened)

* We might want to add some `log::debug!`/`log::info!` logging for the case when we matched, but the path was rejected after FS checks, to simplify the troubleshooting.

Not certain, but also feel that we might want to fall back to URL capturing if nothing custom works?

* Main concern: we seem to synchronously do the string matching with regexes in `process_terminal_event`, in a loop.
This seems quite dangerous, as we can block for quite a long time due to bad and/or abundant regexes.
I think we need to test this bad case more, and, if things start to break indeed (I suppose this will look like "cmd-hover onto some line, nothing else works for a few seconds, even resizing"), we need to consider moving this match-in-for-loop to the background thread.

Thanks for looking at my prototype and sending your feedback. I think I agree with all your points, but I'm not sure my prototype is the best approach. I've been thinking about your earlier comment that regex might not be the right solution, and I think you may be right. I have an idea for another approach that I think is better than my prototype in many respects (and which is probably similar to what you were thinking of when you mentioned nested quotes above...). I would like to discuss the design a bit more before I proceed further.

**Design**

The below non-regex approach could be used for linkifying paths with spaces in the terminal without adding any user config, which seems like a big benefit.

```rust
let focused = /* word under the cursor */;
let potential_start_words = &[/* all words on the same line up to focused */];
let potential_end_words = &[/* all words on the same line from focused to the last word */];
let linkified_path = /* longest string starting with a word in potential_start_words and 
    ending with a word in potential_end_words that is a valid path */;
```

**Benefits**
- No configuration needed, it just works for most (all?) cases.
- Handles nested quotes, parenthesis, etc.

**Drawbacks**
- Does a little more work in the default case (bounded by line length though). If this unacceptable, we could retain the existing behavior of checking the focused word first, and not check further if it is a valid path. Also other mitigations against pathological cases (e.g., very long lines) are trivial.
- It is possible to match an existing file for a focused word that is not _meant_ to be a path, e.g. An existing file named "hello to the world" would be linkified in the sentence "I would like to say hello to the world!". I feel that this would be rare and also, _it matches the existing behavior_ ;), ...and is not solvable in a fully general way.

**Considerations**
- Given the potential drawbacks, it seems best to have this disabled by default, so we would need a setting value to explicitly enable it. I think it _would_ be nice to have it enabled by default, if that were deemed acceptable, but I'd rather have it opt-in than not at all.
- The workspace could tell us if any path in the workspace contains spaces, and we could enable this behavior by default if it does. Of course, it could still be disabled in settings.
- It would also be possible to match on strings enclosed in well-known (or user configured) path-surrounding characters; ' " ( )
- It seems desirable to find the longest match, but I could be wrong.

Honestly, not sure I see any benefits over the regexes as, indeed, we seem to replace regex matching with more heuristics (checking for whitespaces in paths and removing the surrounding symbols) with more FS checks required for this.
We're not going away from regexes fully either, as we're forced to check for URLs at least.

Maybe, I'm missing something and it's simple to prototype this to prove me wrong?

From an implementation perspective, I see them about the same. Where I see real benefits of the non-regex approach are in usability and functionality. For usability, with the regex approach, everyone who wants this feature enabled has to figure out for their specific language and tools which regexes will work for them, and there are 100s of tools at least. Sure any given developer may only have 10s they are working with, but even that is cumbersome. Also, it is brittle; any change in the tools' output can break everyone's regex. For functionality, the regex approach doesn't work for nested quotes, (or ( ) [ ], etc.) or multiple paths on a line (e.g., the default output of `ls` wouldn't linkify). With the non-regex approach, the only configuration needed for everyone's toolset to just work is `enable_linkify_all_valid_paths = true`, it is not brittle, and it works in cases where regex is difficult or impossible. Seems like a good trade for a few extra `fs.exists()` calls, no? I'm happy to put together a prototype for the non-regex approach--I'll work on that and we can think it over in the meantime.

I've pushed the new non-regex prototype here: https://github.com/davewa/zed/tree/terminal-hyperlinks-all-valid-paths
Seems to work nicely. Also, as I was writing that up, I had another idea: _If_ we are willing to limit support to files belonging to the workspace, couldn't we utilize the existing index (???-p) for a cleaner solution?

* Zed codebase prefers to avoid using `std::fs` wherever possible and use `trait Fs` instead: https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/blob/6367754737a3fa4b93c32f8ebd9fe044859f441b/crates/fs/src/fs.rs#L79

Note that this is async and won't work well with the event loop most probably.

*
> couldn't we utilize the existing index

That's what we do exactly: https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/blob/6367754737a3fa4b93c32f8ebd9fe044859f441b/crates/terminal_view/src/terminal_view.rs#L851-L866

On top of that, we do check the relative paths for existence in the worktree the same way.
Note that `terminal.rs` is architectured so that it does not know anything about Zed's internals including `Workspace`

Moreover, this workspace index is not complete and will never include `excluded_files` and gitignored files deep in the tree (until their parents are expanded in the project panel or them/neighbors are opened first).

So this is not a solution, but still a good thing to try first before accessing the FS.


* Do I understand right that `LINE_COLUMN_REGEX` assumes `:` as a separator always?
This will hurt MSBuild output format at least: https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/issues/15412 

Also, unfortunately, all `:`, `,`, `(`, `)` symbols are valid in paths of certain OSes:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0ef04527-64e8-4c45-bc7c-93d1c568aa31)

As nowadays MSBuild is cross-platform, it can generate horrendous edge cases where `New File.txt(2)` could be both an existing file and a link to the 2nd line of another file.

In the new, generic system, how are we going to help both groups that want and do not want MSBuild in their systems?

* Last but not least: traversing lines incrementally, matching them by regexes and doing synchronous FS API calls, totally ignoring existing `MaybeNavigationTarget::PathLike` and relative file resolution, all done in the event loop makes me not enthusiastic at all about the new approach.

That's all really helpful feedback, thanks. For some of those points, I think we were already in a agreement--I am planning to do a lot more work on the prototype.

>  So this is not a solution, but still a good thing to try first before accessing the FS.

This is great! I will update the prototype to integrate with the `terminal.rs` architecture and logic in `terminal_view.rs`

> Do I understand right that LINE_COLUMN_REGEX assumes : as a separator always?

It does, and that is a bug...

> In the new, generic system, how are we going to help both groups that want and do not want MSBuild in their systems?

My plan for this is the same as for the case of the path being surrounded by common symbols: check for the longest potential path, and if it is not a path successively strip off a small, well-defined set of common symbols and possible line/column suffix and check for each shorter variation.

> Last but not least: traversing lines incrementally, matching them by regexes and doing synchronous FS API calls, totally ignoring existing MaybeNavigationTarget::PathLike and relative file resolution, all done in the event loop makes me not enthusiastic at all about the new approach.

My plan is to update the latest prototype to incorporate all your feedback thus far, including using async Fs, using the index before accessing the FS, integrating with the logic in `terminal_view.rs`, supporting the surrounded by common symbols case, and adding lots of tests.

> and adding lots of tests

Note that this might be hard due to 0 visual tests in Zed and 0 tests related to terminal (modulo regexes but even those are merely "matches or not" checks).

Good luck nonetheless.

I've updated https://github.com/davewa/zed/tree/terminal-hyperlinks-all-valid-paths to the point where I'd like additional review and feedback before continuing further. In my testing it is performing and working very well, but much more testing is needed. I do have one big "kitchen sink" test and a few other smaller tests, but there are many edge cases and nuance in this space so I am planning to write many more unit tests for specific cases. All the tests pass on macOS, Ubuntu, and Windows. I'm hopeful that we can reach consensus on the heuristic approach. The prototype currently has both the regex support and the heuristics in a unified design.

Hey @davewa, I looked over your fork a bit, and I think it's looking pretty good overall. I think the best way to proceed is to create a pull request, mark it as a draft and ping me in the comments. That way we can continue discussing implementation details and see up to date diffs more easily. 

I'd also appreciate if you'd make sure the box is checked that says "allow maintainers to edit the pull request" as that usually helps make things go a bit faster and smoother. Thanks!
Sounds good, thanks for looking at it! I'll get a draft PR going next week.

Based on the discussions here and on #27218, I propose the following next steps:

#### Add tests for existing functionality

As @SomeoneToIgnore points out near the [beginning of this issue](https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/issues/12338#issuecomment-2155302926), the first PR(s) should be adding tests for existing functionality (no new functionality). I propose the tests would have input of a mock fs, mock worktree(s) (local and remote), terminal content, working directory, and hovered point. The output would include the hyperlinked match, all maybe paths checked, where they were checked (worktree or file), and any open target if one is found. These would be split between terminal and terminal_view crates and would include any refactoring necessary to enable testing. They should pass on macOS, Linux, and Windows. In order to make the tests maintainable, I've been looking into testing crates with support for snapshot testing, and [insta](https://docs.rs/insta/latest/insta/index.html) looks nice. I don't see it being used anywhere in Zed yet though? I feel this will be super helpful in improving maintainability, especially having different snapshot folders for different OSes, and potentially also for different levels of enabled functionality. The snapshot approach should also help keep build times fast as test coverage increases.

#### Design new functionality

There have been some small comments/discussion on various threads--I'd like to write up the design in one place and check it in. My preference for this is a markdown document, with as simple a description of the requirements and design as possible, plus some illustrative examples.

#### Implement new functionality

Once the design is complete, create small, focused PRs for each step of implementation. This may end up being exactly [as proposed by @SomeoneToIgnore](https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/pull/27218#pullrequestreview-2710424964):
- Support for regexes + background fs checks and timeouts
- Support for levels of functionality, e.g., optional extended `/paths with spaces/` support

(And also my proposal):
- Reuse navigation target computed on hover for open

Although after completing the design we may decide on a slightly different set of PRs.

I'll be working on testing existing functionality next (with [insta](https://docs.rs/insta/latest/insta/index.html)).

Hey @davewa, I appreciate the effort you're putting in to improve this area. 

I have one nit with what you have described here, however, and that is that I don't see a reason to make this more complicated than it needs to be. I think the important part here is just that we identify URLs & paths accurately and _quickly_ (as is reasonable). Once we have the path/URL, it seems trivial to figure out whether it's actually a path in the file system, or send it to the browser if it isn't. Additionally, as far as I can tell, we have had very few issues with the file path pointing to the wrong place (i.e. identifying the wrong file based on the path) so I really don't think testing this step is that important. Therefore, I personally don't see a reason why we would need mock file systems, or snapshot testing, when some simple `text input -> Option<URL>` tests would do just fine.

Beyond just simplicity, however, my understanding is that snapshot testing, by definition, requires some way of "fetching" the previous snapshot. This would be a fairly substantial change to the way our testing and CI works currently, and is almost certainly not something that should be included as part of a small refactor such as this one.


### Suggestions

From my perspective, the reason that we're looking to improve/restructure this codepath, is that the current implementation is complex and hard to modify to extend it's functionality. 

What I'd be interested in is something along the lines of a simple `text in -> Option<URL>`  out structure. Where we have a few builtin parsers (preferably hand written rather than regex, but regex is fine) for the most common cases like `{path}:{row}:{col}`,  `https://{url}`, etc. With the capability for the user to define regex patterns themselves in their settings. 

With that as the base, it becomes much simpler to just extract paths & URLs from terminal text as we come across them, filter the ones that don't exist out (based on the actual file system), link them to a location in the terminal, and reuse that parsed path/url when the user is hovering & subsequently requesting to follow it as you also mentioned. 

With this structure, It also becomes much simpler to test, as we just need a string with a URL or edge case in it to test the URL extraction, and, if we end up wanting tests for the "filter" step, we can deal with MockFS or some other thing that makes sense (we already have ways to create _real_ temporary files/folders in tests) as needed.

With the user-provided regexes, we can also provide some example regexes for styles that are niche enough that they're not worth supporting natively, but worth making available to users in such a way that they just have to paste it in their settings. 

And, if we want to maintain the "parse on demand" behavior we have right now (where urls are only searched for once hovering occurs), that would require a very minimal change to what I've described so far, that being once the user hovers, we extract some bounded region around the cursor and try to parse.

But that's just my two cents, and is in not gospel in any way so feel free to disagree. I'm happy to create a rough first draft of the first steps (extracting out the current implementation to work on text rather than terminal grid) if my explanation isn't making sense for you.

So far I've only refactored FindHyperlink processing in terminal.rs (just to improve it's testability). I haven't done anything with mocks or insta yet. I share your desire for simplicity, and excluding paths with spaces, I think something like what you suggest would be nice. How about this: I add some simple tests for existing functionality to my refactoring of FindHyperlink, and share those before doing anything else? I can post another draft PR if that is the preferred workflow. I think the test coverage is the most important thing that is lacking currently, and looking at actual tests is a great way to build a common understanding of what the use cases are and how much complexity is actually necessary to support those. Currently on stable for example, any path with a unicode character not matched by `\w` in it is failing to linkify for me--that seems like something that really should never be broken. As far as testing just text input, I'm worried that would miss coverage of scenarios that are cell-specific, for example with single unicode characters that are two cells wide (the char in the first cell and wide char spacer in the second cell). How would we write a test which asserts that the link underlines both cells? I'm just learning about how this is handled in alacritty, so my understanding of this is probably not complete, but it does seem like something that should have test coverage.

I should note that my original regex approach does of course work for _some specific_ paths with spaces cases, and we could add (or allow users to add) a regex for each case, i.e., cargo output, rustc diagnostics, python diagnostics, various forms of ls/dir output, etc.. This could end up being a long list of regexes for some people. The heuristic approach in #27218 is required for 1) enabling entire classes of these types of use cases _by default_ and also 2) some use cases which would be extremely difficult (impossible?) with regex. I totally understand if we're not interested in 1) or 2), and I'd be happy to proceed with the regex approach first, get that merged, and then contemplate the demand/cost/benefit of doing further work on the heuristic approach after that. There is also the separate issue of ambiguous cases, e.g., do we want to add support for actual paths that parse into paths with positions? That should be treated as a completely separate issue.

I published a prototype branch here: https://github.com/davewa/zed/tree/terminal-hyperlink-tests

I like that it gives us coverage of the code in `HyperlinkFinder::find_from_grid_point`, which seems fiddly and likely to change. Alacritty RegexSearch does appear to always return matches that do not start or end in-between a wide char and its spacer(s), so those test are probably overly paranoid (although there are some edge cases there which I have not checked yet). If this prototype branch seems like something people would be interested in discussing further and moving forward with, I'd be happy to create a draft PR. If not, I can rework it to only test the regexes, and the match post-processing for row/column/description.

Also, I'd like to propose splitting this issue into two distinct issues:

1. Hyperlink navigation for paths with unicode characters that don't match `\w` (which is a much simpler one to fix, and would enable Mojo, for example)
2. Hyperlink navigation for paths with spaces

Perhaps it would be helpful to summarize where I think we are with this? I clearly went a little overboard by fixing a lot of separate issues at the same time in #27218:

1. (this issue) Paths with unicode characters that don't match `\w`
2. (this issue) Paths with spaces
3. Adding a setting for user regexes for identifying paths and optional positions
4. Ambiguous paths, i.e., `~`,`/a`, `/b`, `:4:2`, `(4,2)`, `'hello.rs'`, etc., are all valid real paths, but we parse them as special cases
5. Reusing open target computed for hover when navigating
6. Supporting all valid paths for each OS, e.g., many valid Linux paths are invalid Windows paths

I feel that each of these should be separate issues (even though some do overlap a bit), each with their own cost/benefits/tradeoffs which we may or may not deem worth fixing. I think it would be nice to start with the simplest which have the most consensus (1, 3, and 5?) and then look at the others.

> for example with single unicode characters that are two cells wide (the char in the first cell and wide char spacer in the second cell). How would we write a test which asserts that the link underlines both cells?

I think this is the kind of thing we should fix when it becomes a problem. My intuition is that it's very rare for this to even occur, and not worth structuring our  solution / testing around (not saying that you are, just to illustrate the point). Worth keeping in mind for sure, so we don't back ourselves into a corner, but not something to super worry about is my takeaway.

Thanks for the summary @davewa, very helpful! I also completely agree. I think 1,3, and 5 are a great place to start. I also took a look at your branch and I think it's a great first step. Feel free to open a PR for it once you're ready. We should also probably create a discussion for this to avoid polluting / pinging people on this this issue.

issueDTO.title: Improve documentation how to setup and use a kopia server
issueDTO.description:
I'm pretty new to kopia and really impressed! In general the documentation is really good and easy to understand fro me. Thank you very much for all you work!

However, now I tried to setup a kopia server and there are some things I missed at https://kopia.io/docs/repository-server/ so these points could be improved. (I might provide a PR for the documentation ... once I understand the details ... :smiley:)

* Explain the process of setting up a kopia server
  * Explain requirements to run a server
  * `kopia server start`, link to https://kopia.io/docs/reference/command-line/common/server-start/
  * Explain TLS setup (*)
  * Remember to open the port in case a firewall is used (e.g. on linux with ufw using: `sudo ufw allow 51515 comment 'kopia server via https'`)
  * Create user accounts
  * Will the server start automatically on machine boot (e.g. register a service)? Or do I need to do this myself?
* It seems that `kopia server start` does not start the server in the background, but instead provides the server itself. I did expect it otherwise, so it might be mentioned. I guess now, the server won't be started automatically then, right?
* what does `kopia server snapshot` (cancel / pause / resume) do? I don't understand the explanation on https://kopia.io/docs/reference/command-line/common/server-snapshot/

(*) Could it be that the headings level got messed up? It looks like "Auto-Generated TLS Certificate" is a sub heading of "Configuring Allowed Users - Kopia v0.7":

* [Configuring Allowed Users - Kopia v0.8](https://kopia.io/docs/repository-server/#configuring-allowed-users---kopia-v08)
* [Configuring Allowed Users - Kopia v0.7](https://kopia.io/docs/repository-server/#configuring-allowed-users---kopia-v07)
  * [Auto-Generated TLS Certificate](https://kopia.io/docs/repository-server/#auto-generated-tls-certificate)
  * ...

But when I read more carefully, it talks about kopia v0.8 as well, so I guess there is a top level heading missing?

-----
Some more experiences during my first steps, as hints how the documentation could be improved:

How can I print the fingerprint again in case I missed to write it down when it was created?

Once I started a kopia server, I try to connect (on server machine):

```
$ kopia server status --server-cert-fingerprint xxx
kopia: error: unable to list sources: 400 Bad Request, try --help
```
This error message is not really helpful and should at least be explained.
But when connection from a remote machine this **did** work:

```
$ kopia repository connect server --url https://<server>:51515 --server-cert-fingerprint xxx
```

When I try to get the server status from a remote machine, this fails as well:

```
$ kopia server status --address https://<server>:51515 --server-cert-fingerprint xxx
kopia: error: unable to list sources: 401 Unauthorized, try --help
```

(BTW: Seems to be inconsistent to use `--address` here and `--url` at other places. Or does it have different semantics?)

Also, when I try to open the server web UI in a browser, the credentials I created before using `kopia server user add` are not accepted.

-----

When I try to sync a local repo to the server I also get an error:

```
$ kopia repository sync-to server --url https://<server>:51515 --server-cert-fingerprint xxx
kopia: error: expected command but got "server", try --help
```

Is syncing to a server not supported or did I miss something here? It did work when I tried `filesystem` or `sftp`.

-----
$ kopia --version
0.10.7 build: 5d87d817335f6d547e094ab80062113dc3a1fdf4 from: kopia/kopia
comments: Hi, I'm also trying to understand the `kopia server snapshot` usage

> How can I print the fingerprint again in case I missed to write it down when it was created?

This is not generated. This is the "cleaned up" fingerprint of the TLS certificate:

`openssl x509 -noout -fingerprint -sha256 -in <public.crt> | sed 's/://g' | cut -f 2 -d =`

I think the problem here goes beyond just documentation. The server seems to be variously broken and/or very problematic to work with. I've spent the last couple of days beating my head against the server with the following results:

---

It's confusing that some `server` commands accept control params for directly accessing a remote server (also noting the inconsistent use of the params `--url` and `--address` accross various subcommands, as above), whereas others do not, and appear to require connecting to a repository before they can be used. This can maybe be aided by documentation, but the CLI would be much more usable if all server operations were implemented on the control API, or alternatively (and much less preferably), operations that actually operate on the respository were put under a nested subcommand, ie `server repository users list` or something.

---
 
- The `server status` command on the host does not work, always returns `400 Bad Request`.
- The `server status` command executed remotely, using the correct control username and password returns `400 Bad Request`
- The `server status` command specifies that it reads the env vars `KOPIA_SERVER_USERNAME` and `KOPIA_SERVER_PASSWORD` as the values for the args `--server-control-username` and `--server-control-password` respectively, however the variables for the control user when starting the server are `KOPIA_CONTROL_USER` and `KOPIA_CONTROL_PASSWORD`, resulting in conflicts for configuration via env.
- The KOPIA_CONTROL_USER variable name is inconsistent with the KOPIA_SERVER_USER*NAME* variable name (and the latter format should be preferred as it's consistent with the argument names `--server-control-username`/`--server-username`).

---

- The `server refresh` command on the host does not work, always returns `400 Bad Request`.
- The `server refresh` command executed remotely, using the correct control username and password returns `400 Bad Request`
- The `server refresh` command specifies that it reads the env vars `KOPIA_SERVER_USERNAME` and `KOPIA_SERVER_PASSWORD` as the values for the args `--server-control-username` and `--server-control-password` respectively, however the variables for the control user when starting the server are `KOPIA_CONTROL_USER` and `KOPIA_CONTROL_PASSWORD`, resulting in conflicts for configuration via env.
- The KOPIA_CONTROL_USER variable name is inconsistent with the KOPIA_SERVER_USER*NAME* variable name (and the latter format should be preferred as it's consistent with the argument names `--server-control-username`/`--server-username`).

It's possible all the control-api commands produce these results, but the above two are the ones that I tested.

---

I could not find any way to get both the CLI and the server to see that they're connected to a repository other than to first create the repository from the CLI (e.g. `kopia respository create ...`), then to log into the server web UI and connect the repository from there too. This is quite confusing - is the server not using the same configs as the CLI or something?

---

After creating a user via `kopia server users add user@host`, connecting to the repository on a client `kopia repository connect server ...`, and receiving the expected response:

```
Connecting to server 'https://127.0.0.1:51515' as 'user@host'...
Connected to repository API Server.

NOTICE: Kopia will check for updates on GitHub every 7 days, starting 24 hours after first use.
To disable this behavior, set environment variable KOPIA_CHECK_FOR_UPDATES=false
Alternatively you can remove the file "/home/user/.config/kopia/repository.config.update-info.json".
```

No repository commands work:

```
$ kopia snapshot create /home/user/tmp
ERROR failed to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for user@host: EOF
ERROR open repository: unable to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for user@host: EOF
$ kopia snapshot list
ERROR failed to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for user@host: EOF
ERROR open repository: unable to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for user@host: EOF
$ kopia repository status
ERROR failed to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for user@host: EOF
ERROR open repository: unable to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for user@host: EOF
```

Maybe this is because the `server refresh` command is broken and can't be executed, however restarting the server also has no impact, and `repository connect` succeeds so I suspect this is a more fundamental problem.

I tried enabling ACLs but they made no difference.

---
So my steps to this point, performed on Kopia v0.13.0 (I'm doing dev locally, so the server host here is a docker container, but AFAICT this is all equally valid for a hand-rolled server install):
1. On server host, bring up server via `kopia server start ...`
2. On server host, create local repository via `kopia repository create filesystem ...`
3. On server Web UI, connect local repository
4. On server host, create a user via `kopia server users add ...`
5. On client, connect repository via `kopia repository connect ...`
6. Fail

At this point I think I've exhausted all the options I can find as a user, without putting my dev hat on and going to try to hack the code. It doesn't help that the `debug` log level rarely seems to output anything more than the `info` level, which outputs the bare minimum - decent logging would probably make diagnosing this stuff vastly easier.

Also some UX adjustments would be nice. For example `kopia server users add User@Host` will gladly prompt for a password, twice, only to stop you with

```console
$ kopia server users add User@Host
Enter new password for user User@Host:
Re-enter new password for verification:
ERROR error setting user profile: username must be specified as lowercase 'user@hostname'
```

Same happens with `kopia repository connect server --url=http://somehost:51515`. It validates arguments only after prompting for credentials.

```console
$ kopia repository connect server --url=http://localhost:51515
Connecting to server 'http://localhost:51515' as 'username@hostname'...
Enter password to open repository:

ERROR failed to open repository: invalid server address, must be 'https://host:port'
ERROR error connecting to API server: invalid server address, must be 'https://host:port'
```
---

As a side question: is there a reason why Kopia connects to the repository server over HTTPS only? I've seen a generic "due to gRPC" answer [here](https://kopia.discourse.group/t/cant-connect-to-insecure-repository-server/871/3), but no further explanation. There was an issue about the same topic, but it went stale: #1215. A quick google search reveals that gRPC can work over plain HTTP. See e.g. grpc/grpc-go#555

I want to report that I am also experiencing "permission denied" errors when connecting to a Kopia server over TLS. Having followed the documentation quite closely.

```
kopia repo connect server --url=https://192.168.1.106:51515 --server-cert-fingerprint ####
```
```
[info] ERROR failed to open repository: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: unable to initialize session: rpc error: code = PermissionDenied desc = access denied for ####@#####: EOF
```

This error message occurs on the client (Windows 11), but on the server host (macOS) nothing comes up in the stdout.

Also, can we get _actual_ docker environment variables instead of this command line argument stuff shoehorned into a compose file?

```
KOPIA_PASSWORD="<password-for-the-repository>" \
KOPIA_SERVER_CONTROL_PASSWORD="<server-control-password>" \
  kopia server start \
    --tls-generate-cert \
    --tls-cert-file ~/my.cert \
    --tls-key-file ~/my.key \
    --address 0.0.0.0:51515 \
    --server-control-username control
```

Having to mix mounted volumes with absolute cert file paths when there are often already mount points for these is quite patchy and there is no reason to do so.

Additionally, there should absolutely be documented accepted environment variables by the container like many other docker apps have.

https://github.com/imagegenius/docker-kopia?tab=readme-ov-file#parameters

https://immich.app/docs/install/environment-variables/

and of course, no mention in the documentation to go the very common path of no-tls on a secure home network. The client works without it, but the server just throws errors that it is expecting TLS.

`Connect Error: INTERNAL: internal server error: connect error: error opening repository: error connecting to API server: unable to establish session for purpose=: error establishing session: Session(): rpc error: code = Unavailable desc = connection error: desc = "transport: authentication handshake failed: tls: first record does not look like a TLS handshake"`

I was wondering about "GRPC needs TLS" too, so I asked my friend ClaudeAI about it:

> Let me clarify this:
>
>gRPC does not strictly require TLS (Transport Layer Security). You can run gRPC without TLS in what's called "plaintext" mode. However, using TLS with gRPC is highly recommended and considered best practice for several reasons:
>
>1. Security: TLS provides encryption and authentication
>2. Modern browser requirements: Web browsers require TLS for HTTP/2, which gRPC uses
>3. Production environments: Most production deployments require TLS for security
>
>You can use gRPC without TLS in:
>- Development environments
>- Testing scenarios
>- **Internal networks where security requirements are different**
>- Situations where performance is critical and the network is already secured

Besides that there is this fingerprint being used to identify or validate the server, which would need a replacement when running without TLS.

Official docs on how running a repository server it's like a dog chasing its nail. I know this is an open source free project but how is it possible that there's no one who can explain the correct sequence to have a repository server correctly up and running with some clients putting their snapshots there? I have faced all errors reported above and the best suggestion you have on the forum is to look at some YouTube videos... really? Clear documentation is a must and unfortunately many awesome open source projects have not it.

Hello +1 here

3h i fight with docs with help on AI to try to do (what i think should be) a simple case : to have root creating backups and one user to consult. with the recommandation to use a local Kopia Server.

Infos are splitted in several parts and pages, melded with others infos.
And for example "starting a server page" even don't mention the server start command.

I think too that this kind of basic case should be covered simply in a one page. Like local userland only, local with Server and differents users (like root + users), local with docker, remote (if not simple to add the exception in other cases).

I see the problem to provides one page full example of the most basics cases will lead to duplicate some informations in case to update (and then risk to forget to update one command or option change), but doc should be primary user-oriented, and not everyone able to read all the docs, identify all the subparts to take from all thos pages to make the global picture.

Ok, if someone wanna create a strange exceptional scenario, but not for a simple architecture.

issueDTO.title: Storybook: Add and Update Block Editor Components stories
issueDTO.description:
## What problem does this address?
<!--
Please describe if this feature or enhancement is related to a current problem
or pain point. For example, "I'm always frustrated when ..." or "It is currently
difficult to ...".
-->
Most of Block Editor components don't have stories.
Block Editor components's Storybook should also be added and updated like the Components.
related #22891

## What is your proposed solution?
<!--
Please outline the feature or enhancement that you want and how it addresses any
problem identified above.
-->
We can use this issue to track the addition and updating of the stories for Block Editor.
You can add the link to assign yourself to each component.
As I know, Block Editor Components list has never existed, so at first, we can start to be based on the directory name.
The list was made automatically, and we can ignore the component for native only.

If you cannot edit the list, please comment on which you made the PR for which directory's components.

cc @WordPress/gutenberg-components 

## Best Practices

### 1. Use CSF 3 format

Write stories as objects, not functions

<details><summary>Do</summary>

```jsx
export const Default = {
	render: function Template( { onChange, ...args } ) {
		const [ value, setValue ] = useState();
		return (
			<SomeComponent
				{ ...args }
				onChange={ ( ...changeArgs ) => {
					onChange( ...changeArgs );
					setValue( ...changeArgs );
				} }
				value={ value }
			/>
		);
	},
};
```

</details> 

<details><summary>Don't</summary>

```jsx
const Template = ( { onChange, ...args } ) => {
	const [ value, setValue ] = useState();
	return (
		<SomeComponent
			{ ...args }
			onChange={ ( ...changeArgs ) => {
				onChange( ...changeArgs );
				setValue( ...changeArgs );
			} }
			value={ value }
		/>
	);
};

export const Default = Template.bind( {} );
```

</details> 

### 2. Consists of only one component
 
The purpose of Storybook is to test a single UI component itself. Therefore, unless there is a special reason, we should not include anything other than that component.

### 3. Don???t create too many stories

While it's tempting to expose as many variations of a component as possible, the behavior of the component can be changed in the Controls section.

Therefore, additional stories should only be included if they involve significant visual or behavioral changes.

### 4. About meta data

To display the source panel by default, specify `'shown'` in [the `meta.parameters.docs.canvas.sourceState` field](https://storybook.js.org/docs/api/doc-blocks/doc-block-canvas#sourcestate).

<details><summary>Example</summary>

```javascript
const meta = {
	// ...
	parameters: {
		docs: {
			canvas: { sourceState: 'shown' },
			// ...
		},
	},
	// ...
};
```

</details> 

Define the component description via the `meta.parameters.docs.description.component` field instead of a comment.

<details><summary>Example</summary>

```javascript
const meta = {
	// ...
	parameters: {
		docs: {
			// ...
			description: {
				component: 'Component description here...',
			},
		},
	},
	// ...
};
```

</details> 

Explicitly define the type of props via the `meta.argTypes.{propName}.table.type.summary` field.

<details><summary>Example</summary>

```javascript
const meta = {
	// ...
	argTypes: {
		// ...
		propName: {
			// ...
			table: {
				type: {
					summary: 'string',
				},
			},
		},
		// ...
	},
};
```

</details> 


For private components, you may want to define the following fields to display the badge 🔒 ([Private APIs README](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/blob/trunk/packages/private-apis/README.md)).

Check [here](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/blob/f1fadbb036f1e702e3a28072444fd0de28a5dc02/packages/block-editor/src/private-apis.js#L57-L100) to see if the component is exported as private.

<details><summary>Example</summary>

```javascript
const meta = {
	// ...
	tags: [ 'status-private' ],
	// ...
};
```

</details> 

### 5. Others

If the component you're working on doesn't have a README or JDoc, I'd appreciate it if you could do the following to clarify the component's implementation first:

- If there's no README file: This is part of https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/22891. If the component already has JSDoc, you can use it to help write the README.
- If there's no README and no JSDoc: You'll need to analyze the component's implementation and clarify the types of props and return types. See https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/22891#issuecomment-2543030487 for information on the JSDoc format.

- [x] block-alignment-matrix-control https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/pull/67292

Hey @miminari,

I have submitted a PR for the following components:

- [x] text-alignment-control https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/pull/67371
- [x] text-decoration-control https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/pull/67337
- [x] contrast-checker https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/pull/68120

I'm curious about the reasoning here :). I'm not saying we shouldn't be doing this but curious to lean what value you folks will be receiving from this ?

cc @WordPress/gutenberg-core for awareness.

I see a couple benefits from the maintainer side:

- Improve engineering quality. Working in the isolated story when iterating on the component (as opposed to working directly in the Gutenberg app) promotes better engineering standards because it forces you to think about encapsulation, clear interfaces, etc.
- Increase iteration speed. Having a story is much faster for discovery and testing different states. You don't have to dig around the app to see where the component is used, figure out what states exist, and how to reproduce them.

I honestly don't know if there is pure documentation value for the extenders.

I'd like to emphasize that we should write the stories in a way that **keeps maintenance cost at a minimum**. It will quickly become a net-negative if the stories incur a maintenance cost. For example, avoid hardcoded values as much as possible, and try to structure things in a way that will not need fixing when the underlying component code changes. Don't write unnecessary descriptions, as those are another thing that need to be updated manually when things change. Let's start with the simplest possible.

As a plugin developer, I find Storybook extremely useful.

When implementing a UI for a custom block or block editor, I can see what components are exposed, what props are supported, and how they work.

Without Storybook, it's hard to imagine how something would work unless I actually wrote the code while reading the documentation, or found a place in the Gutenberg repository where the component is actually used.

I noticed that some components have the `__experimental` or `__unstable` prefix.

I wondered if I should publish these components to Storybook, but some components with these prefix have already been published.

If the component has a proper README and code examples, I believe it's okay to publish it to Storybook.

Thanks to everyone working on this issue. Although not directly related to this issue, I noticed that some components don't have a README or JSDoc.

If the component you're working on doesn't have a README or JDoc, I'd appreciate it if you could do the following to clarify the component's implementation first:

- If there's no README file: This is part of #22891. If the component already has JSDoc, you can use it to help write the README.
- If there's no README and no JSDoc: You'll need to analyze the component's implementation and clarify the types of props and return types. See [this comment](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/22891#issuecomment-2543030487) for information on the JSDoc format.

Excellent team effort here.

@t-hamano, your tips and suggestions should be included in the issue description. It's helpful information and is currently hidden in GitHub activity. We could use the `details` element to collapse the component list. It's taking up too much space, in my opinion.
@Mamaduka Thanks for the feedback! I've summarized all the tips and suggestions in the description.
Update: I would like to propose adding badges (🔒) to private components. Please see the "4. About meta data" section of this issue for more details.

Update: I noticed that some components are internal and not public, so I updated the list. For internal components, it is marked as `(Internal) component`.

We need to consider whether to expose internal components to Storybook.

If we do, it may be useful for Gutenberg contributors, but it will not be useful for the extenders.

Personally, I don't think internal components need to be exposed. However, some PRs have already been submitted for internal components, so we will need to close them. Sorry, I should have noticed this sooner.

I look forward to your comments.
Unlike private components, I think there is no intention of publicizing internal ones, so exposing them doesn't make sense.

Okay, so let's not add Storybook to the internal components. I will update the list and close the PRs that have already been submitted as well. I apologize to everyone who worked on these issues 🙇?????????
We should also avoid adding stories for deprecated components. Deprecation means that consumers should avoid using these components, so there's no need to "promote" them via Storybook.

> We should also avoid adding stories for deprecated components.

That's true. I've added the `(Deprecated)` to the deprecated components.
Hello @miminari, Is this issue still open? If so, can I work on this?

issueDTO.title: value|defaultValue={Symbol|Function} should be ignored, not stringified
issueDTO.description:
Regression in master from https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/11534.
Found it thanks to the attribute fixture snapshots.
comments: Just for clarity: This is the correct behavior for Symbols: With my change, `value` and `defaultValue` never pass through the property sanitation layer. React tries to stringify symbols, which throws an error, and functions get turned into `"function () {}"`.

Now that I looked at this again, *the update codepath was already broken*. This just made the initial code path match it. So this is actually an improvement. We should still get https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/11741 to completion to have consistent *sane* behavior, but IMO this is not as urgent as I thought at first.

Fairly sure this should be closed. Looking at the behaviour of both `input` and `textarea` elements, when they are passed, as `value` or `defaultValue`, a function or a symbol, they will never stringify this. For `value`, they will have a console error. For `defaultValue`, they will not, as shown in this table:

| Markup                             | Shows error | Renders stringified version |
|-----------------------------------|------------------|-------------------------------------|
| `<input value={() => {}}>` | Yes | No |
| `<input defaultValue={() => {}}>` | No | No |
| `<textarea value={() => {}}>` | Yes | No |
| `<textarea defaultValue={Symbol("test")}>` | No | No |
| `<input value={Symbol("test")}>` | Yes | No |
| `<input defaultValue={Symbol("test")}>` | No | No |
| `<textarea value={Symbol("test")}>` | Yes | No |
| `<textarea defaultValue={Symbol("test")}>` | No | No |


As shown in this code: https://codesandbox.io/s/pedantic-fast-25khi0

I may have misunderstood things :D But it seems like this is resolved
Hello @gaearon, Is this issue resolved? if not, can I work on this one...?

When using the syntax "value|defaultValue={Symbol|Function}" in a code implementation, it is typically intended as a way to provide default values for a variable or parameter. The use of symbols or functions as default values can be a powerful tool in certain cases, such as when dealing with complex or dynamic data structures.

When it comes to stringification, however, it is generally not recommended to stringify symbols or functions. This is because symbols and functions are not simple data types that can be easily converted to strings. When they are stringified, they lose their original functionality and become simple strings, which can cause unexpected behavior in the code.

Therefore, it is recommended that when using "value|defaultValue={Symbol|Function}" syntax, the symbols or functions should be handled and evaluated directly in the code, rather than being stringified. This will ensure that their original functionality and intended behavior are preserved.

issueDTO.title: About the automatic carriage return problem of pasting part
issueDTO.description:
### What would you like to be added?

Remove the paste return to prevent the message from being automatically sent when pasting.

### Why is this needed?

About the automatic carriage return problem of pasting part

During use, we often need to paste some errors, codes, etc. into cli for communication, but I found that now no matter in the web editor, carriage return will be attached when pasting. This will cause me to send the problem directly after pasting. But in fact, I didn't finish writing. But when I stopped by esc, I tried to retrieve the previous conversation, but it disappeared, and I could never complete the pasting operation.

Another way is to copy and paste it into an unformatted part first, such as WIN+R to run the input box before copying and pasting it into cli. I think this is a very big problem and seriously affects development efficiency.

I wonder if the last space can be automatically cleaned when pasting to prevent sending messages before editing is completed.

Now as long as it involves me entering some text, and then I try to combine errors in multiple locations to ask questions. It can't be completed at all. I tried \ enter shift, but it didn't work.

### Additional context

_No response_
comments:
Ubuntu and some bespoke Linux here. Miraculously in Gemini CLI's GUI the EOL marks in the pasted snippets so far have been rightly converted to some marks that do not trigger sending the command. (That is: I do not have this problem). 
(While e.g. Grok AI's GUI is awful in that respect indeed: every copied string from its own GUI appends  double EOLs, methinks) 


Two tips for now: 
A. Just keep a scratchpad file open in the same folder so that Gemini can access it. Then you can paste there anything, without worrying. Gemini then shall read it via `read_file` when you tell her to do so. Just keep that TXT file open in another window: `gedit`, `notepad` etc. one.  
B. Describe what to do, then add some "code here:" as an informal marker between intent and source, and the code as the source (that may indeed trigger execution then).

It is a method, I understand what you mean. Create a temp.txt file to handle pasting. But many times we don't need a large text, such as a small error message, which can also cause this problem. I understand that it is because of system reasons and some IDEs or webs have implicit line breaks, which I think should be automatically cleaned up. I can indeed use the method you gave for the time being. Thank you for your reply.

Thanks for flagging this, @ISensuiI! Accidental sends on paste are annoying. A quick fix could be:

1. **Trim trailing newlines on paste** before inserting text.  
2. **Use Shift+Enter** for new lines; only plain Enter sends.  
3. **Guard on send**???strip any leftover newline before submitting.

I???d love to tackle this???could you please assign #3953 to me? I can draft a small PR with these handlers if you???re on board! 🙏🏾

Yes, thank you very much for helping me complete the PR. Is there anything I can do? Or can you just submit a PR and reference the current issue? I have never submitted a PR myself, so I don't know the correct process. How should I proceed?

Myself I thought about using MS PowerToys for this to do on fly replacement, but I was also thinking about another solution that is more advanced (to my level) that will do this automatically by detecting the Terminal window name and thus applying the replacement exclusively to that window without even having to remember anything (sort of set and forget). But I also thought about something like Windows Commander Palette plugin that will sort of type the text and by modifying to replace the new line chars by Ctrl+Enter (I think it can work but I need to test the idea, yet it can be slower than it should to do it this way and also cause all sort of UX undesirable situations.)

Tomorrow hopefully I will try to learn more about this and what would be the best options to have to circumvent this issue, but I hope that Gosling will come up with an elegant solution that will make all my tinkering obsolete.

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: Load mappings on demand, restore mappings when done debugging
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

When I installed vimspector, I only really expected to use it every now and again (debugging real-time systems is usually better via a UART and gdb only comes out in desperate cases).  The "Human" mappings sounded sensible for general use, but I was then surprised that all my previous F-key mappings had disappeared - I expected them to appear when I first ran vimspector or did a `packadd` or something like that.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Include an autoload command called something like `vimspector#LoadMappings "human"` (perhaps with a default that can be saved in vimrc) that saves existing F-key mappings ([useful reference here](https://vi.stackexchange.com/a/7735)) somewhere and then installs the F-key mappings.  Also include an autoload command called something like `vimspector#UnloadMappings` that restores whatever you had before loading vimspector.

Loading mappings could also be automatic when you first run a Vimspector command/function, but I wouldn't mind it being a (single) manual step.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

For now, I've removed the `g:vimspector_enable_mappings` thing from my vimrc, but that means that when I want to debug something I have to do one of:

* Edit vimrc and then restart vim (which loses all the tabs, splits etc)
* Manually do the mappings, then manually undo them when I'm done
* Write my own function to do LoadMappings / UnloadMappings
comments:
You can use this https://github.com/puremourning/vimspector?tab=readme-ov-file#custom-mappings-while-debugging

BY default vimspector doesn???t set any mappings unless you ask for them. A hook already exists to set your own custom mappings in debug start/end  (I use this myself for some non-Fkey) mappings. 

I mean I guess I could move the mapping code to a function you can call with the mode but it???s like 10 LOCs: https://github.com/puremourning/vimspector/blob/5e24df822e278ee79abfc8c7110089a5322d1a3c/plugin/vimspector.vim#L137 and all the PLUG mappings are documented so I???m not seeing this as a priority. Maybe would accept a PR with tests though.

