issueDTO.title: Save `journalctl` before and after the whole plan execution
issueDTO.description:
Add Test checks Plugin that will save journalctl content before the test, and then again when test finishes.

```
check:
  - name: journalctl
```
comments: @dupliaka Can tmt save just output produced during test's execution or it should be whole output each time?
Ah, so 'test run' means 'tmt run', not the execution of the test itself.

> It should contain logs from prepare and finish steps as well so it is rather the whole output.

That could be rather tricky since `check` is a `test` level variable. It might be available at least after `discover`, but then there could be plugins that would need to run `discover` after the `prepare`, e.g. for CMake, there would be a `prepare` step added to configure (+build), only then it can run `discover` to get the tests to evaluate.

One solution is to allow `check` to be on plan level as well, which will give an overall `journalctl` for the plan execution, and `test.check` would be surrounding only the `test.execute` section

> > It should contain logs from prepare and finish steps as well so it is rather the whole output.
> 
> That could be rather tricky since `check` is a `test` level variable. It might be available at least after `discover`, but then there could be plugins that would need to run `discover` after the `prepare`, e.g. for CMake, there would be a `prepare` step added to configure (+build), only then it can run `discover` to get the tests to evaluate.
> 
> One solution is to allow `check` to be on plan level as well, which will give an overall `journalctl` for the plan execution, and `test.check` would be surrounding only the `test.execute` section

And indeed, that is the plan :) We just started with the test part because it seemed easier to achieve, but plan-level checks will happen.

issueDTO.title: Post-Delete Hook support mutate Application object
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

The recent [Post-Delete hook support PR](https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/pull/16595), mutate the Application object when refreshing by [adding two finalizers](https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/blob/fcf5d8c2381b68ab1621b90be63913b12cca2eb7/controller/appcontroller.go#L1630-L1643) if a resource have a `"helm.sh/hook": post-delete` annotation.
In an apps of apps context it causes unnecesssary reconciliations due to object updated:

`{"api-version":"argoproj.io/v1alpha1","application":"myRootApp","cluster-name":"myCluster","fields.level":0,"kind":"Application","level":"debug","msg":"Requesting app refresh caused by object update","name":"myApp","namespace":"argo-cd","server":"myServer","time":"2024-03-07T08:14:40Z"}`

**To Reproduce**

Create an Application that deploy another Application, in the nested Application deploy a resource that have a `"helm.sh/hook": post-delete` annotation. Wait for the 3m default refresh interval and search for the `Requesting app refresh caused by object update` debug log line.

**Expected behavior**

Do not mutate the Application object or at least maybe automaticaly ignore thoses finalizers like it is currently done for the metadata fields `generation` and `resourceVersion`

**Version**

```shell
argocd: v2.10.2+fcf5d8c
  BuildDate: 2024-03-01T21:24:51Z
  GitCommit: fcf5d8c2381b68ab1621b90be63913b12cca2eb7
  GitTreeState: clean
  GoVersion: go1.21.3
  Compiler: gc
  Platform: linux/amd64
```
comments:
A possible workaround:

```yaml
resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application: |
  jqPathExpressions:
    - .metadata.finalizers[]? | select(. == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io" or . == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup")
    - if (.metadata.finalizers | length) == 0 then .metadata.finalizers else empty end
```
@alexmt Hello, can I have your opinion on this please ? do you consider it as a bug or normal behavior ?
we are experiencing the same issue. The workaround above works, but it looks like this should be handled on argocd side

> A possible workaround:
> 
> ```yaml
> resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application: |
>   jqPathExpressions:
>     - .metadata.finalizers[]? | select(. == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io" or . == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup")
>     - if (.metadata.finalizers | length) == 0 then .metadata.finalizers else empty end
> ```

how can i make that in config map ?

> > A possible workaround:
> > ```yaml
> > resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application: |
> >   jqPathExpressions:
> >     - .metadata.finalizers[]? | select(. == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io" or . == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup")
> >     - if (.metadata.finalizers | length) == 0 then .metadata.finalizers else empty end
> > ```
> 
> how can i make that in config map ?

not sure to understand your question, the example is what you must add to the `argocd-cm` ConfigMap

In case this was useful somehow, here it is a good example of a "real world" chart triggering this: 

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/node-feature-discovery/blob/6030c974d38ed9a1e4592f0f133d64e27d3c50a7/deployment/helm/node-feature-discovery/templates/post-delete-job.yaml#L8-L10

which is used in NVIDIA's gpu operator:

https://github.com/NVIDIA/gpu-operator/blob/main/deployments/gpu-operator/Chart.yaml#L21
@nbarrientos, which ArgoCD version are you using when reproducing?
@andrii-korotkov-verkada Hi! `v2.12.6+4dab5bd`

We're also experiencing the same as @nbarrientos, NVIDIA GPU Operator including NFD.

Argo CD v2.12.3+6b9cd82

Experiencing the same with the current latest kyverno helm chart :)
Using argo-cd v2.12.3+6b9cd82

> Experiencing the same with the current latest kyverno helm chart :) Using argo-cd v2.12.3+6b9cd82

Agreed - we just ran into this with the latest Kyverno chart as well due to https://github.com/kyverno/kyverno/pull/11504.

Why are extra refreshes an issue? They are normal to happen a lot, e.g. when some pods are updated and watches identify there's an update. If they are slow, try 2.13.1, there's been some major perf improvements for when it comes to reconciliation.

@andrii-korotkov-verkada No the issue we have is that our app-of-apps applications show up with a `diff`:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a5fe505b-f9ce-45fe-a81b-b1f2aca40a1e)
Which diffing strategy are you using? Is it default or server side diff?

Server side diff can be enabled on the controller level as well as application level and has some logic to remove webhook mutations when diffing. If you use server side diff and don't explicitly add webhook mutations and see this, let me know, as it could be a bug in that logic.

> Which diffing strategy are you using? Is it default or server side diff?

Hmm. We have not made any changes - so whatever the default is in the latest ArgoCD.

Then you are using legacy, at least I don't think we've switched to server side diff by default.
Try that out https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user-guide/diff-strategies/#enabling-it.

For now - the ignoredifferences fix works for us.. Going into the holidays, I'm hesitant to change the apply method (we have thousands of applications across dozens of argocd installations... it would be risky!). Either way, just reporting here that this is definitely a bug that should be fixed (regardless of the apply-policy).
btw, I think this comment is relevant, especially for Kyverno users: https://github.com/kyverno/kyverno/issues/9451#issuecomment-2134984772

We are using kyverno (helm chart version: 3.3.4) and our argocd is v2.13.2

we are still getting the same error even after adding the annotation 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2dbc5064-27ae-45d0-b54a-ebdf409ad01a)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/77472f0a-6119-485c-aa0a-d568c680f230)

this is when we are doing apps of apps

We're facing the same issue with `teleport-kube-agent` Helm chart
ArgoCD version is v2.12.6+4dab5bd
No server-side diff enabled on controller nor app-of-apps Applcation
Issue still present in 2.13.4
Also still in 2.14.1

@gdsoumya, @llavaud  [asked for comments](https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/17433#issuecomment-1984413432) about the described behavior from the feature developer but there hasn't been any reply, unfortunately. Could you please give your opinion on this issue as change reviewer?
I have updated to 2.14.11 and this problem seems to be now fixed, at least in the Kyverno case. CC @nbarrientos ???
Actually, it still happens.... but it seems to sync much faster than before, so the App does not stay outofsync for more than an instant... not sure this will be fine for everyone.

> A possible workaround:
> 
> resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application: |
>   jqPathExpressions:
>     - .metadata.finalizers[]? | select(. == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io" or . == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup")
>     - if (.metadata.finalizers | length) == 0 then .metadata.finalizers else empty end

I tried using this. It fixed the app out-of-sync issue, but blocks the deletion of the application.

> > A possible workaround:
> > resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application: |
> > jqPathExpressions:
> > - .metadata.finalizers[]? | select(. == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io" or . == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup")
> > - if (.metadata.finalizers | length) == 0 then .metadata.finalizers else empty end
> 
> I tried using this. It fixed the app out-of-sync issue, but blocks the deletion of the application.

that is weird, this rule just ignore these fields for reconciliation but don't prevent the controller to add or remove the finalizers

> > > A possible workaround:
> > > resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application: |
> > > jqPathExpressions:
> > > - .metadata.finalizers[]? | select(. == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io" or . == "post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup")
> > > - if (.metadata.finalizers | length) == 0 then .metadata.finalizers else empty end
> > 
> > I tried using this. It fixed the app out-of-sync issue, but blocks the deletion of the application.
> 
> that is weird, this rule just ignore these fields for reconciliation but don't prevent the controller to add or remove the finalizers

@llavaud I was wrong. 
The patch works correctly but the deletion of Kyverno Argo app is stuck with the following error:

"Forbidden: no new finalizers can be added if the object is being deleted"

This happens when I delete the parent argo app.

For anyone following the thread:

I started running into this issue after upgrading to Kyverno 1.13. It was due to a post-delete hook which got introduced in the chart. The post-delete helm hook was also causing problems with the argo app cleanup. 
I got around it by setting `config.preserve: false` in the Kyverno chart. This setting disables the post-delete hook. It is anyways, not relevant for a ArgoCD based install.

I'd like to make a quick summary so that we can work towards closing this issue.
- Argo CD supports post-delete hooks (Helm hooks and regular resource hooks as an annotation)
- The current implementation adds 2 finalizers on the Application CR in the case when a post-delete hook was identified (`post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io` and `post-delete-finalizer.argocd.argoproj.io/cleanup`)
- For Apps managed with Git, setting those finalizers results in a contradiction with Git's source of truth
- A known workaround is setting a `resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application` globally or per App
- Since the drift is introduced by an internal Argo CD behavior, and not by user behavior, it seems beneficial to make Argo CD ignore this diff OOTB, without requiring additional user actions 

**Action items:**
- Make sure the problem still exists (deploy a Helm chart with a post-delete hook or deploy an App with a manifest annotated as PostDelete and see whether a diff is produced)
- If so, one proposed solution is to enable a default ignore differences configuration for those 2 finalizers

A workaround is to set a `resource.customizations.ignoreDifferences.argoproj.io_Application` globally or per App. The issue is not specific to Helm charts, but also affects Apps with manifests annotated as PostDelete.

issueDTO.title: Move the blocks build output directory from `dist/assets/js/blocks` to `dist/assets/blocks`
issueDTO.description:
## Feature Description

The assets built for blocks are a mixture of JS, CSS and JSON, however they are output to the directory `dist/assets/js/blocks`.

We should move the location up a level, to `dist/assets/blocks`, to make the organisational structure clearer.

---------------

_Do not alter or remove anything below. The following sections will be managed by moderators only._

## Acceptance criteria

* The blocks build assets should be placed in `dist/assets/blocks` rather than `dist/assets/js/blocks`.

## Implementation Brief

* [ ] Update `assets/webpack/gutenbergBlocks.config.js`, changing the following lines removing `js/` from the paths:
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/assets/webpack/gutenbergBlocks.config.js#L67
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/assets/webpack/gutenbergBlocks.config.js#L117
* [ ] Update all of the following assets URLs within the PHP side of the plugin, removing the `js/` from the paths:
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L521
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L536
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L545
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L560
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L576
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L588
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager.php#L599
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Sign_In_With_Google.php#L315
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Sign_In_With_Google.php#L323
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager/Contribute_With_Google_Block.php#L77
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Reader_Revenue_Manager/Subscribe_With_Google_Block.php#L77
   * https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/444fc0796e3cb30d27ed389bb0ec572b5a28b6f0/includes/Modules/Sign_In_With_Google/Sign_In_With_Google_Block.php#L66

### Test Coverage

* No test coverage required.

## QA Brief

* Enable Sign In With Google and RRM
* Smoke test the Reader Revenue Manager blocks in the block editor.
* Smoke test the Sign In With Google blocks in the block editor.

## Changelog entry

* N/A

issueDTO.title: Unknown Model (mobilenetv5_300m_enc) when loading Gemma 3n
issueDTO.description:
### System Info

```bash
- `transformers` version: 4.53.0
- Platform: Linux-6.1.141+-x86_64-with-glibc2.35
- Python version: 3.10.12
- Huggingface_hub version: 0.33.2

- PyTorch version (accelerator?): 2.5.1+cu121 (NA)
- Tensorflow version (GPU?): 2.17.1 (False)
- Flax version (CPU?/GPU?/TPU?): 0.10.2 (cpu)
- Jax version: 0.4.33
- JaxLib version: 0.4.33
- Using distributed or parallel set-up in script?: <fill in>
```

Does Gemma 3n require special setups? That is not sustainable. 

### Who can help?

I upgraded to the latest transformers to try Gemma 3n and it would seem there is not implementation of mobilenetv5_300m when i try to run the model as described on the official huggingface page.

```bash
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
[<ipython-input-2-ac178faa1642>](https://localhost:8080/#) in <cell line: 8>()
      6 model_id = "google/gemma-3n-e4b-it"
      7 
----> 8 model = Gemma3nForConditionalGeneration.from_pretrained(model_id, device_map="auto", torch_dtype=torch.bfloat16,).eval()
      9 
     10 processor = AutoProcessor.from_pretrained(model_id)

8 frames
[/usr/local/lib/python3.10/dist-packages/timm/models/_factory.py](https://localhost:8080/#) in create_model(model_name, pretrained, pretrained_cfg, pretrained_cfg_overlay, checkpoint_path, scriptable, exportable, no_jit, **kwargs)
    111 
    112     if not is_model(model_name):
--> 113         raise RuntimeError('Unknown model (%s)' % model_name)
    114 
    115     create_fn = model_entrypoint(model_name)

RuntimeError: Unknown model (mobilenetv5_300m_enc)
```

Does Gemma 3n require special setups? That is not sustainable. 

### Information

- [x] The official example scripts
- [ ] My own modified scripts

### Tasks

- [ ] An officially supported task in the `examples` folder (such as GLUE/SQuAD, ...)
- [ ] My own task or dataset (give details below)

### Reproduction

The example code on the model card 
```python
from transformers import AutoProcessor, Gemma3nForConditionalGeneration
from PIL import Image
import requests
import torch

model_id = "google/gemma-3n-e4b-it"

model = Gemma3nForConditionalGeneration.from_pretrained(model_id, device_map="auto", torch_dtype=torch.bfloat16,).eval()

processor = AutoProcessor.from_pretrained(model_id)

messages = [
    {
        "role": "system",
        "content": [{"type": "text", "text": "You are a helpful assistant."}]
    },
    {
        "role": "user",
        "content": [
            {"type": "image", "image": "https://huggingface.co/datasets/huggingface/documentation-images/resolve/main/bee.jpg"},
            {"type": "text", "text": "Describe this image in detail."}
        ]
    }
]

inputs = processor.apply_chat_template(
    messages,
    add_generation_prompt=True,
    tokenize=True,
    return_dict=True,
    return_tensors="pt",
).to(model.device)

input_len = inputs["input_ids"].shape[-1]

with torch.inference_mode():
    generation = model.generate(**inputs, max_new_tokens=100, do_sample=False)
    generation = generation[0][input_len:]

decoded = processor.decode(generation, skip_special_tokens=True)
print(decoded)
```

### Expected behavior

This is the basic example on the model card.

issueDTO.title: Lots of warnings `WARNING:player data has no entry for en: list index out of range`
issueDTO.description:
We regularly have significant numbers of warnings `WARNING:player data has no entry for en: list index out of range`

This happens for instance once for `3d printing` topic (which is quite small, so this is cool to debug):
```
[ted2zim::2024-07-10 13:00:14,290] WARNING:player data has no entry for en: list index out of range
[ted2zim::2024-07-10 13:09:10,718] INFO:Total video links found in 3d printing: 14
```

Sample command to see the "bug":
```
ted2zim --name "ted_test" --topics "3d printing" --format webm --low-quality --tmp-dir tmp --output output
```

Problem seems to occur on https://ted.com/talks/dan_walker_can_we_print_smart_objects video

I'm not sure but this looks like an intentional WARNING saying "something is probably not ok", even if a fallback is available.

We should have a look at why this is occurring to confirm whether this is just "normal" (but then we should probably move the log level to debug, it is mostly useless to have so many "normal" warnings) or if there is a real issue to solve.
comments:
Um, this happens mostly because there is no available subtitle for the video in the language. I examined the player data and the `languages` list is empty which means there is no subtitle for the video. Visited the link to confirm and it definitely seems to be the case. IMO, I think it's a good logging level because the user can see that there is an indication of something wrong but the program is still working as expected. In the case of the code, the language is set to a default for the native language.

EDIT: Keeping it at a debug level, the information could be hidden and that might not be particularly useful to the user. However, I think we can re-word the error to be more descriptive. What do you think?
Thank you for the analysis. I like the idea of re-wording the message, especially if we can including information about which video is concerned (its slug or something like that).

repository.description: Provide the best of TED.com for offline usage!
repository.name: ted

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to investigate and fix the `WARNING:player data has no entry for en: list index out of range` warning, which occurs when there is no available subtitle for the video in the language.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue should be confirmed whether it's just 'normal' or if there is a real issue to solve. The logging level should be checked to see if it's necessary to keep it at a debug level or if it can be changed to a more informative level.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author analyzed the issue and found that the language is set to a default for the native language. They also suggested re-wording the error message to be more descriptive and including information about the video concerned.
summary.otherNotes: The issue seems to occur because there is no available subtitle for the video in the language. The `languages` list is empty, which means there is no subtitle for the video. The author suggests re-wording the error message to be more descriptive and including information about the video concerned.

issueDTO.title: Write tool which can convert translated files back to PO
issueDTO.description:
This idea is from https://github.com/rust-embedded/book/issues/326: we should write a converter tool which takes two Markdown files as input and outputs a PO file.

More concretely, the tool should take an `en/foo.md` and `xx/foo.md` file and output a `xx.po` file. The tool will call `extract_messages` on both files and line up the results. It will use the messages from `en/foo.md` as the `msgid` and the corresponding message from `foo/xx.md` as the `msgstr`.

The output is marked fuzzy to ensure that a human translator double-checks it all before publication.
comments:
I'd be happy to take a look at this!

It would be a separate bin crate then?

~~Are there any good example .md files? Or should I just generate them myself from some already translated mdbook?~~
I've generated some example files myself (with po4a) to work with.

Hejsa! Thanks for looking at this!

I was thinking to use some of the [Rust book translations](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/appendix-06-translation.html) to start with, e.g., pick one here which is somewhat current and which you can read :slightly_smiling_face: 

The [Rust Embedded book](https://docs.rust-embedded.org/book/#translations) is also translated into a few languages ??? that's where the idea came from.

You might want be able to reuse some of the logic in [`mdbook-i18n-normalize`](https://github.com/google/mdbook-i18n-helpers/blob/main/src/bin/mdbook-i18n-normalize.rs). That tool takes a PO file looks at each `(msgid, msgstr)` pair. It then runs `extract_messages` on both to get two lists:

```rust
let msgids = ["msgid_1", "msgid_2", "msgid_1"];
let msgstrs = ["msgstr_1", "msgstr_2", "msgstr_1"];
```

Finally, it zips those lists and output the `("msgid_N", "msgstr_N")` pairs to the PO file. Having written this, it occurs to me that this is what your tool will have to do as well.

One feature your tool could have would be to (attempt to) synchronize the translations on various points. So if the source text is

```markdown
# The Foo Project

Welcome to the Foo projects...

## Getting Started

To install Foo, do ...
```

and the translated document is

```markdown
# Foo-projektet

Velkommen til Foo-projektet...

## Komme godt igang

For at installere Foo, ...
```

then the conversion tool could align on the `#` and `##` headings. This would make it robust against extra paragraphs being inserted in either language.

Similar with lists and block quotes, they could perhaps also be synchronization points. This is just an idea, I'm not sure it's useful :smile:

> It would be a separate bin crate then?

I missed this part, I think it could just be a new binary next to the others to start with. If people like the tool but somehow don't want to see `mdbook-*` binaries on their system, then we could consider moving this binary to its own crate. Luckily, mdbook-i18n-helpers is already a library crate, so it's easy to depend on it from other crates.

>I think it could just be a new binary next to the others to start with.

Yes, that's what I mean by "separate bin crate". I agree that we might do a separate "package" later on if needed.

Additionally, I'm a bit held up at the moment with other work, but I'll keep working in this whenever I have the time.

>I was thinking to use some of the [Rust book translations](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/appendix-06-translation.html) to start with

From that link, how do I get the actual translated .md file? It seems that all that's available is either .po or .html files.

Hejsa!

> > I think it could just be a new binary next to the others to start with.
> 
> Yes, that's what I mean by "separate bin crate". I agree that we might do a separate "package" later on if needed.

I see, great!
 
> Additionally, I'm a bit held up at the moment with other work, but I'll keep working in this whenever I have the time.

That's completely fine, I know the feeling :smile: 

> > I was thinking to use some of the [Rust book translations](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/appendix-06-translation.html) to start with
> 
> From that link, how do I get the actual translated .md file? It seems that all that's available is either .po or .html files.

Clicking through to the Swedish translation (to keep a Scandinavian theme ??? I'm from Denmark and I guess you're from Sweden), leads me to https://github.com/sebras/book/tree/master/src where I see a bunch of translated files. So I would use these two files an a starting point:

- https://github.com/sebras/book/blob/master/src/ch00-00-introduction.md
- https://github.com/rust-lang/book/blob/main/src/ch00-00-introduction.md

I'm not sure if the idea actually works... will 10% of the paragraphs line up, or 80%? Just from skimming those two files, it looks like a lot of text lines up very nicely.

Hejsan!

I've (finally) started looking into this. The code required is pretty straight forward for reading, parsing and extracting. The hard part is the syncing. Having looked at a couple different translations of the book, they can differ a lot, a little, or not at all.

Some examples.
Filename: number-of-extracted-messages

ch00-00-introduction.en.md: 45
ch00-00-introduction.sv.md: 46

ch01-02-hello-world.en.md: 45
ch01-02-hello-world.sv.md: 42

ch02-00-guessing-game-tutorial.en.md: 177
ch02-00-guessing-game-tutorial.pt.md: 252

Trying to line them up might work in really simple scenarios, where the structure is still intact. But in the PT case above, the EN version is really far ahead. The main problem I see is that there is a lack of context in the MD files. If a single heading (or other sync point of choice) is left out in either file, the remaining message pairs will be garbage. Even with a small difference like 42 vs 45, there is no way to tell if the diff was at message 1 or 40.

So what is "good enough" here? Should we fail as soon as something appears to be off? Or greedily try to do what we can? What's the threshold? Strict or lax? Need some guidance here.

Btw, having run just my own tool (which calls `extract_messages()`) a number of times, closing down my editor and my terminal, I get a number of zoombie processes that linger consuming CPU. (I only noticed this because this is the first time ever the fan on my M3 has started.) Is this expected?

> Trying to line them up might work in really simple scenarios, where the structure is still intact. But in the PT case above, the EN version is really far ahead.

That is a very good point and I don't think there is a clear right answer here.

Our `mdbook-i18n-normalize` tool has a similar problem: it normalizes a `.po` file by re-applying the extraction logic. The idea is that we've improved the way we extract messages over time and so this tool lets you migrate an old `xx.po` file to benefit from the latest improvements. Biggest example of this: we used to extract a Markdown table as a single unit, now we extract the text cell by cell.

When we normalize each `(msgid, msgstr)` pair, we run into similar problems as what you have here: we could easily end up with different number of extracted messages from each of `msgid` and `msgstr`. The normalization tool handles this in a very primitive way here:

https://github.com/google/mdbook-i18n-helpers/blob/2b14491962254ec2ff3f12ffeb59f09f7f4686ae/i18n-helpers/src/normalize.rs#L203-L220

If there are extra messages in the `msgstr` field, it accumulates them in the final `msgid` field. This is confusing in its own way and indirectly lead to #125.

> The main problem I see is that there is a lack of context in the MD files. If a single heading (or other sync point of choice) is left out in either file, the remaining message pairs will be garbage. Even with a small difference like 42 vs 45, there is no way to tell if the diff was at message 1 or 40.

You mention a "sync point"... which is something we haven't looked into before! For the use case of generating a `.po` file from two `.md` files, I think establishing some sync points could be very helpful. This could be Markdown features which we hope are stable over time:

- headings of different levels
- lists
- tables
- block quote

and perhaps others?

I haven't thought this through, but I could imagine using a [largest common subsequence or diffing algorithm](https://florian.github.io/diffing/) to find common parts of the Markdown AST between the two documents.

The flow would be something like this:

1. Extract the AST for each document
2. Normalize all text so that you're left with a normalized outline. Something like

   ```markdown

   # Heading 1
   ## Heading 1.1

   Paragraph 1 in 1.1

   Paragraph 2 in 1.1

   - Item 1 in 1.1
   - Item 2 in 1.1

   Paragraph 3 in 1.1
   ```

   Here I'm thinking that it'll be good to include the heading numbers in the normalized paragraph and list item text to give the diffing algorithm something to "attach to"?

3. Diff the two normalized documents. Everything that matches gives you a mapping from `msgid` (from the first document) to `msgstr` (the second document). Things that are extra in the second document can be dropped, things that are missing in the second document just have a `msgstr` equal to `""`
4. Go back from the normalized outlines to the original documents and output a `.po` file.

At the end of the day, one document will be the source. So regardless of what the translated document contains, the source will win: if there are 10 paragraphs in the source document, then there should also be 10 paragraphs in the translation. This is kind of a built in limitation of the way we attempt to chop up the source document when we do translations.

> Btw, having run just my own tool (which calls `extract_messages()`) a number of times, closing down my editor and my terminal, I get a number of zoombie processes that linger consuming CPU.
> (I only noticed this because this is the first time ever the fan on my M3 has started.)
> Is this expected?

Nope, I would not expect this ??? everything in this library should be completely in-process and not spawn anything. It only does text to text transformations.

The `group_events-...` name is interesting: we don't have a binary with that name, so I guess it comes from somewhere else?
Hi @memark, let me unassign this for now ??? we can assign it back to you or someone else later when activity picks up.

> I haven't thought this through, but I could imagine using a [largest common subsequence or diffing algorithm](https://florian.github.io/diffing/) to find common parts of the Markdown AST between the two documents.

## Overall idea
When thinking about this I also think this is best done by matching on the AST.
Lets parse the markdown with pulldown_cmark and use the [`Event`](https://docs.rs/pulldown-cmark/latest/pulldown_cmark/enum.Event.html)s as symbols without the content. E.g. `Text("foobar")` just becomes `Text`, `Start(Tag)` and `End(TagEnd)` have important structural information in [`Tag`](https://docs.rs/pulldown-cmark/latest/pulldown_cmark/enum.Tag.html) and [`TagEnd`](https://docs.rs/pulldown-cmark/latest/pulldown_cmark/enum.TagEnd.html) and are kept. All elements that are structural informations are kept.

The sequence should still store enough information in such a way that we can recover the original document.

Now we want to get the best matching between the two structural sequences.

## Algorithms
Let's compare some algorithms. Bioinformatics has to deal a lot with sequence matching, so this is a good inspiration 
- [Longest Common Subsequence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence) (LCS): Finds the longest common subsequence that appears in the same order in both sequences. This would provide us with all elements that are actually equal and makes it easy to dismiss the "extra" bits. As far as I understand, it only matches unmodified bits of structure. If someone changes an element to a different type this will be missed.
- [Needleman-Wunsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Needleman%E2%80%93Wunsch_algorithm): Performs global alignment over the entire length to find the best overall match. This is usually used if two sequences are similar and of roughly equal size. This would just match up the structure as good as possible and could deal with the issue of translators changing the structure to a different type.
- [Smit-Waterman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smith%E2%80%93Waterman_algorithm): Performs local alignment that identifies regions of high similarity within the sequences. Usually this is used for dissimilar sequences that are suspected to contain regions of similarity. Not the best fit for our use case.

Let's think about this for a minute:

The Longest Common Subsequence can exactly provide what we need. It would try to match the structure and all structures that match are returned and this has with high probability (but not 1.0) matching content that was translated. It discards every changed structural element (`[A B C]` ??? `[A D C]`) but would keep the `[A C]` elements. In reality a lot of algorithms provide a vector of changes so we could also see these inserts, deletions.

The last two could also be candidates for the problem we face. From these I would propose the global [alignment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequence_alignment#Global_and_local_alignments) as by definition, the second document is a document that was once the exact same structure but differed (ideally) only by the non-structural text that is invisible to the algorithm. This would allow to try to match (`[A B C]` ??? `[A D C]`) in a way that it recognized that `B` was *edited* into `D`. Which might be wrong but could be true.

I don't think it really matters for our usecase if we use a LCS or a Needleman-Wunsch and they both should provide similar output. The later just seems to be a bit more flexible in the sequence comparison.

## Crates:
### Longest common Subsequence
[crates](https://crates.io/search?q=longest%20common%20subsequence)
- [lcs_rs](https://crates.io/crates/lcs_rs) (v0.1.1): API requires strings, does not return changes
- [slice-diff-patch](https://crates.io/crates/slice-diff-patch) (v1.2.4): works with parametrized vectors of elements (supporting `PartialEq`. [provides change vector](https://docs.rs/slice-diff-patch/1.2.4/slice_diff_patch/) (insert, remove, update,...). Looks very promising
- [diffs](https://crates.io/crates/diffs) (v0.5.1): This supports a Binary, a Meyers (used for git) and a Patience (git also supports this, more human readable diff). This might be usable but the documentation is pretty slim, has [tests as examples](https://nest.pijul.com/pijul/diffs:main/XNQ4AFHIXFKIQ.CEAAA) and might support our use case.


### Needleman-Wunsch
[crates](https://crates.io/search?q=needleman-wunsch):
- [stringzilla](https://crates.io/crates/stringzilla) (v3.12.5): heavily optimized string matching crate, leveraging SIMD. using [`[u8]` in the API](https://docs.rs/stringzilla/3.12.5/stringzilla/sz/fn.alignment_score.html). While this might be usable if our structural elements are translated to numbers, I don't see how I can get the alignment operations as a result.
- [needleman](https://crates.io/crates/needleman) (v0.2.0): API expects two strings and I don't see how I can get the alignment as result.
- [seal](https://crates.io/crates/seal) (v0.1.5, last release 3 years ago...): This is a generic API that just needs a (equality) compare function between elements of both sequences. And it supports both local and global alignment, even if I don't think local would give as any advantage but this is easily testable.

### What crate will I use?
I will pick the LCS supporting crate [slice-diff-patch](https://crates.io/crates/slice-diff-patch) (v1.2.4) because the API supports parameterized vector elements, it provides a change vector and there was a recently release.

My next favorite option would have been [seal](https://crates.io/crates/seal) (v0.1.5) which supports Needleman-Wunsch and also supports parameterized vector elements, provides a change vector. But its last release is 3 years ago and has a low version number, indicating not much support.


## Challenges:
The problem gets difficult once there are extra regions because we don't know which `B` of the sequence `ABBA`, `ABBBA` was introduced newly. We could try to provide some additional hints for that case by using the text length of this structure as an additional property. `A(_) B(20) B(10) A(_)` and `A(_) B(23) B(50) B(8) A(_)` would lead to the conclusion that B(50) was added in the second structure.

## Ideas for encoding the structure to deal with structural changes:
- Structural Elements are encoded into Enum Variants and we dive as deep as necessary into the elements and keep all structural information
- Text is encoded by substituting each word with a new Enum Variant `Word` (or `Letter`, `Sentence`) under the assumption that translations use roughly the same amount of words but different amount of letters per word (and differently ordered). Some testing / benchmarking might provide us with data. The existing po files are the perfect source for generating data if `Letter`, `Word` (split by whitespace) or even rougher as `Sentence` (split by dot - or more generic non-whitespace separators) are better (because each sentence might be translated to exactly once sentence, providing perfect matching opportunities). Paragraphs are already encoded in the [Tag](https://docs.rs/pulldown-cmark/latest/pulldown_cmark/enum.Tag.html) but might otherwise also be an opportunity.

The above comment describes how the markdown structures could be matched up. Assuming for now this work properly, we would still need to create the po file.

Problem: `mdbook_i18n_helpers::extract_messages()` is extracting messages but not storing any structure.

How to proceed from here? Match up both docs and create an intermediate doc.
# Run LCS
Run the LCS algorithm for both documents and build understanding on the equal, updated (in a structural sense), removed or added elements.
## Note
Be aware that there is very likely no perfect match if the content length (letters, words, sentences) is somehow taken into account in the structure. Running the LCS with the text length as a guiding information is nice but this information should probably not be taken into account in the next steps.

# How to use the result
## Create aligned version of both documents
We need to create intermediate aligned versions of both documents for the next steps
### Inner Join or Perfect match
Create a perfectly matched version of both documents. Keep only the perfect **matching** elements and disregard everything that was **added**, **removed**, **updated**. This could be used for the first po version.
The translated documents can then already be generated but would likely miss some things.
This is OK thought as then the original document can be parsed again with the usual process and new text can be added as usual.

### Alternative: Left Join
Create a "Left Join" version of the matched up original and translated docs. Keep everything that is **equal** or where something in the translation was **removed**. This requires marking the translation as unavailable. Elements **added** or **updated** (structural) in the translation are not used.
This would generate a version that already contains all input from the original source but disregards additions / modifications in the translated doc.
#### Idea for future
Keep updated elements as well if a special CLI parameter is set. It is a bit unclear how to proceed with **updated** elements as this could be either a translator modifying the structure (change list to paragraph etc.) or it was a combination of remove from original + adding in translated doc. Likely not very useful but depending on how translators worked in the past this could be an option. This needs to be flagged for the user to have a special look at. 

## Create translation.
Once the structure is aligned, it should be easy to run `mdbook_i18n_helpers::extract_messages()` for both aligned documents, zip the messages into an catalog and create a po file from that.

I quickly tested the matching approach and with the `lcs_diff` I can properly match up the [german translation](https://rust-lang-de.github.io/rustbook-de/ch00-00-introduction.html) of the [introduction](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch00-00-introduction.html) of the rust lang book.

I used this page as test because it is long and has the challenge of a Note section in the beginning. This can be properly detected. But there is some merging of remove + insert operations into an update operation that is not working properly for code + softbreak situations. These happen when there is a code block at the end of a line followed by a softbreak.

A solution would be to override this behavior or even better use the underlying function [lcs_diff::diff()](https://docs.rs/lcs-diff/latest/lcs_diff/fn.diff.html) directly. The patch function that is offered by the [slice-diff-patch](https://crates.io/crates/slice-diff-patch) crate is not worth the additional trouble.

I need to clean my draft code up a bit, add the extract messages part and create the final catalog

Note: LCS seems to work well with specific cases but overall a Needleman-Wunsch algorithm might produce better results.

e.g. in the case:
- Heading, Text(A, 10 Sentences), Text(B, 20 Sentences), Text(C, 30 Sentences)
- Heading, Text(B, 20 Sentences), Text(C, 30 Sentences)

This might produce a matching of A->B (with additions) and B->C (with additions) and C -> not yet translated

It turns out it is difficult to work with cmark event streams. While this is not entirely bad, there is still a lot of tuning necessary.

Another thought might be to use AI for this (oh no, he said AI! ;) ). Not in a "just give it two markdown files and create the po" prompt style but actually compare embeddings of (parts) of the original and translation. Then the similar embeddings should point us to the right pairs of translated paragraphs

issueDTO.title: Enable more revive linter rules
issueDTO.description:
In #5505 we introduced a `revive` linter, but had to disable many of its rules because they were breaking on some places in the code. https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/blob/b38d2f9bc18806b6e716f6f666a786f0aca7d912/.golangci.yml#L154

We can re-enable those rules incrementally by fixing the corresponding breaks one rule at a time (`make lint` should succeed) and removing the disabling entry from the config.

Strong advice: DO NOT OPEN A PR without discussing the impact of the specific linter on this issue first. We don't want very possible linter - some of them are stupid, others require a lot of code changes with minimal benefits.
comments: Is it okay to remove multiple rules in the same PR ?
Only if the changes are really small. I would recommend not mixing different changes / rules in one PR.

https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/blob/fe700fe5c3ed1febd8c610a731cb762a4773eff6/.golangci.yml#L199-L201
Enabling this doesn't break anything, so does that mean it's working fine?

@yurishkuro enabling this
```
 # looks like a good linter, needs cleanup
 - name: confusing-naming
   disabled: true
```

I found and fixed 20 real violations where functions differed only by capitalization (like `startOTLPReceiver` vs `StartOTLPReceiver`), which genuinely confused their purpose. The rule prevents cognitive overhead during code reviews and makes the codebase more readable for new contributors.

@yurishkuro If the above pr looks good, I will start working on the linter rule:
```
 # definitely a good one, needs cleanup first 
 - name: argument-limit 
   disabled: true 
```

issueDTO.title: 🧹 Help us clean up duplicate (or unnecessary) libraries in Context7
issueDTO.description:
Hey everyone,

We need your help to clean up libraries in Context7.

While searching for a library, if you come across multiple instances of the same one, please report them under this issue. Include a screenshot or a short note about what you searched for and what you found, and we???ll clean up the duplicates.

Besides duplicates, you can also suggest libraries you think should be deleted???just let us know which ones and why.

Thanks in advance!
comments:
A few questions about the quest:

**Garbage Collection**: Has the project considered automated removal based on usage metrics? Libraries unused/not-queried for 60+ days could be auto-removed since adding them back is trivial. This avoids manual bias and prevents "_popularity contest_" dynamics where newer libraries get unfairly targeted or someone just doesn't like an approach.

**Duplicate Detection**: I've tried submitting duplicates before and the system blocked me, so some detection exists. If not already implemented, hashing submissions and checking against existing github url would be straightforward and inexpensive to prevent duplicates upfront.

The "suggest libraries you think should be deleted" approach is a perfect example of the popularity contest issue - manual curation risks favoring established libraries over promising newcomers. Usage-based cleanup seems more objective and scalable.
Yep we already check for duplicates, we will think about usage based cleanup thanks for the feedback!

https://context7.com/context7/docs_astral_sh-uv, https://context7.com/astral-sh/setup-uv and https://context7.com/llmstxt/docs_astral_sh-uv-llms.txt are duplicates of https://context7.com/astral-sh/uv

https://context7.com/llmstxt/staging_bryntum-products-calendar-llms.txt is a duplicate and should be deleted, it's based on staging server

Actual library: https://context7.com/llmstxt/bryntum-products-calendar-llms.txt
Hey @cobrabr are you sure if setup-uv is the same as uv?

This is somewhat an adjacent issue: I use TailwindCSS extensively, and the references often jump between v3 and v4 links. Even in v4 itself, the LLM pulls the wrong topic.
Today's example was perfect.
We wanted to test the TailwindCSS typography plugin, but the topic "typography plugin @plugin directive v4" pulling from "context7/tailwindcss" instead landed upon "Load Legacy Tailwind Plugin with @plugin directive".
There are clearly more relevant items in the entire library: 
https://context7.com/context7/tailwindcss
But perhaps a library with 500k tokens bears a higher risk of misdirection? I can't even call this hallucination. It's clearly searched and landed on the wrong topic.

hey Tenelia. The snippet about Legacy Tailwind Plugin exist in all docs resources including docs repo. I dont know how to filter it out. I hope AI agent would be smart enough to not to use a code flagged legacy.

https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss.com/blob/main/src/docs/functions-and-directives.mdx#_snippet_11

It doesn't seem feasible because it still gets picked up in the wrong way. A misdirection causes the AI to thread the needle wrong, leading to a cascading series of missing imports, syntax issues, etc. Are you able to grep and remove sections? As things scale, you may need to have batch jobs setup for each lib.

summary.attemptedFixes: The issue mentions that the system blocks submissions for duplicates, and hashing submissions and checking against existing GitHub URLs would be a straightforward and inexpensive way to prevent duplicates upfront. There are also discussions about removing sections using grep and setting up batch jobs for each library as the project scales.

There are also discussions about the potential for manual curation to favor established libraries over newcomers and the need for a more objective and scalable approach.

issueDTO.title: Remove dead code
issueDTO.description:
### Requirement

Remove dead code from the repository

### Proposal

Use official `deadcode` tool to identify unused code https://mfbmina.dev/en/posts/golang-deadcode/. It currently lists quite a few functions and packages.

### Recommended process

1. Run deadcode tool and pick ONE package to focus on.
2. Post a comment to this issue stating which package you're working on
3. Do not just delete the package / function, do some research first
   * find where (which PR) the function was introduced and what was using it & why
   * ideally find the PR in which that usage was removed without removing the function itself
   * post your findings in the comments to validate with maintainers that it's ok to delete

I don't know how accurate it is but AI says that staticcheck's deadcode detection doesn't work for exported functions that may be used in other packages

> Whole-program analysis limitations: In previous versions, Staticcheck had a "whole-program mode" (--unused.whole-program=true) which aimed to find unused exported identifiers even across a large program. However, this mode was removed in Staticcheck 2020.2 due to issues with caching and flakiness. Currently, Staticcheck's primary dead code detection (U1000) will consider all exported package-level identifiers as used, even if they are otherwise unused in the immediate package. This means it might not catch dead exported functions or types that are part of a library but are never imported or called by any consumers of that library. For finding true "whole-program" dead code (across multiple packages in a large monorepo, for example), you might need complementary tools or approaches.

## Working on: `cmd/collector/app/sanitizer/cache/` package
- when introduced: PR #67 
  - The cache package implemented a auto-refreshing cache system for service names:
    - `ServiceAliasMappingExternalSource` - load mappings from external sources
    - `ServiceAliasMappingStorage` - mappings to storage
    - `autoRefreshCache` - auto-refresh from both sources with intervals
    - used by `NewServiceNameSanitizer()` to map service aliases to canonical names

- When usage was removed: PR #3631 
  - added `NewEmptyServiceNameSanitizer()` as replacement
  - Created `NewStandardSanitizers()` function that excluded the cache-based sanitizer and alsso the cache-based `NewServiceNameSanitizer()` was never included in standard sanitizers

- I have not found any production usage:
  - `NewServiceNameSanitizer()` only used in test files (`service_name_sanitizer_test.go`)
  - Current `NewStandardSanitizers()` only includes:
    - `NewEmptyServiceNameSanitizer()` (simple, no cache)
    - `NewNegativeDurationSanitizer()` (simple, no cache)

Files that can be removed safely:
`cmd/collector/app/sanitizer/cache/` (entire directory)
`cmd/collector/app/sanitizer/service_name_sanitizer.go`
`cmd/collector/app/sanitizer/service_name_sanitizer_test.go`

This seems to be replaced by the solution in PR #3631 but the original implementation was not cleaned up.

I verified this is not a false positive. The cache package defines its own cache interface that's completely separate from the actively used `internal/cache.Cache` interface

So no commits ever removed the usage, as there was no uage to remove. PR #3631 added `NewStandardSanitizers()`, but this actually the new functionality, not replacing cache usage. I think it may be unused since day one. The removal is still safe but the past context i provided is incorrect.

issueDTO.title: Switch from `BatEnum` to `Seq`
issueDTO.description:
In #975 some code was switched from eagerly-constructed lists to the standard `Seq.t`.
However, there's still many places where `BatEnum`/`Enum` is used, which offers similar lazy-sequence functionality.

We could try switching to the more standard `Seq.t` in those `Enum` instances, as long as there's no performance regression from doing so.

After #1443 and #1784, only a handful of instances remain:
- [ ] `BatFile.lines_of` and `BatIO.lines_of`. We'll have to find a sensible way of doing that.
- [ ] `BatCache`. We only use `manual_cache` which is just a thin wrapper around `Hashtbl`. We could easily just have a version in `Goblint_std`.
- [ ] `BatEnum.uniq`. There is no `Seq.uniq` or equivalent. We probably could just avoid that anyway by deduplicating smarter using sets.

repository.description: Static analysis framework for C
repository.name: analyzer

summary.main: Switch from BatEnum to Seq in the analyzer, specifically in places where Enum is used
summary.validationOrRequirement: No performance regression from switching to Seq
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about switching from BatEnum to Seq in the analyzer, specifically in places where Enum is used, as long as there's no performance regression. The remaining instances to be addressed are BatFile.lines_of, BatIO.lines_of, BatCache, and BatEnum.uniq.

issueDTO.title: Feature: Add option to disable "Open in Windows Terminal" context menu item
issueDTO.description:
### What feature or improvement do you think would benefit Files?

Hello,
I would like to request the ability to disable the "Open in Windows Terminal" option from the context menu when right-clicking on folders.
Currently, when right-clicking on a folder in Files, this option appears in the context menu, but it cannot be disabled through the Settings menu.
It would be great to add it to the list of context menu items that can be toggled on/off in the Settings, similar to other customizable context menu options already available.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e3a104db-c5cd-4b32-adf8-23dea78c2482)

### Requirements

This proposal will accomplish adding a toggle option in Settings for the "Open in Windows Terminal" context menu item.

### Files Version

3.9.1.0

### Windows Version

10.0.19045.5965

### Comments

_No response_

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: generate internal export names using frequent characters first
issueDTO.description:
### What problem does this feature solve?

Currently `output.minifyInternalExports` generates export names incrementally from `'a'`.
https://github.com/rolldown/rolldown/blob/a3a4228c16289091eccb66451ce47785f7ecadbe/crates/rolldown/src/stages/generate_stage/compute_cross_chunk_links.rs#L475-L476
But given that the source code normally contains some characters more than other characters, it is better to use those characters first so that the minified code is smaller when compress by gzip.

oxc_mangler uses this pre-computed character list.
https://github.com/oxc-project/oxc/blob/f717da9ba8449afe5b5e9e6730b45efc8927877b/crates/oxc_mangler/src/base54.rs#L30-L31
I think we can use this list for `output.minifyInternalExports` as well.


### What does the proposed API look like?

Not an API change.
comments: @hyf0 @sapphi-red  hi, Whether the function replaces to_base64 with oxc's base54 or replaces CHARS with Align64
The main point is to make `to_base64` to use characters that are frequent first.
@sapphi-red  Thank you for your answer. Insert the collect characters function when iterating the entry chunk, then sort by frequency of use to get a sorted vec?

repository.description: Fast Rust bundler for JavaScript/TypeScript with Rollup-compatible API.
repository.name: rolldown

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to optimize the internal export names generation for `output.minifyInternalExports` by using frequent characters first, inspired by oxc_mangler's approach, to reduce the output size when compressed by gzip.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to use frequent characters first in the internal export names generation, which is expected to reduce the output size when compressed by gzip.
summary.attemptedFixes: The main point is to make `to_base64` use characters that are frequent first. It was suggested to insert the collect characters function when iterating the entry chunk, then sort by frequency of use to get a sorted vec.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to optimizing the internal export names generation for `output.minifyInternalExports` to use frequent characters first, which is inspired by oxc_mangler's approach. The proposed solution does not involve API changes.

issueDTO.title: [FEATURE]: Multimodal Model Support
issueDTO.description:
### Feature request

We want Dynamo to offer and support robust, disaggregated serving for a wide range of multimodal models-including vision-language models (VLMs), audio models, and multi-image inference. To do so, we need to broaden EPDD???s support to cover more models and data types. 

In addition to the currently supported models, we should support all state-of-the-art multimodal models for disaggregated serving -- and not just for vision/image but also audio and video. [This MR](https://github.com/ai-dynamo/dynamo/pull/1388) did a lot of work generalizing the existing multimodal example to work for more models, but there is still more to do with respect to testing additional models and iterating on that work if needed. Ideally, adding support for a new model should be as easy as changing a few fields in the config:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2ad75707-df05-434e-872d-c463e3fcc239

### Describe the problem you're encountering

We're currently only confirmed to support LLaVA 1.5, Qwen2-VL, Qwen2.5-VL, and Phi3V/Phi3.5V with aggregated serving, and LLaVA for disaggregated serving.

### Describe alternatives you've tried

_No response_

issueDTO.title: Follow button is enabled on accounts on blocked domains
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

If the user has blocked domain X, and then views an account on domain X, the "Follow" button is present and enabled. 

**To Reproduce**

1. Block a domain (e.g., mastodon.social)
2. View an account on that domain (e.g., search for an account known to be on that domain)
3. Open the account details page
4. See Follow button is enabled
5. Click button, get 403 error

**Expected behavior**

Button is shown disabled. Possibly, clicking on it shows a toast with a "You cannot follow this account, you have blocked $domain" message. Possibly with a button to remove the domain block.

**Versions**

2.14.0

issueDTO.title: Auto-approve sub-options remain visually enabled when "Enable auto-approve" is unchecked
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

When "Enable auto-approve" is unchecked in the Auto-approve Settings, all the sub-options (Toggle all, Read project files, Read all files, Edit project files, Execute safe commands, Use the browser, Use MCP servers) remain visually enabled and appear clickable. The user expected these options to be grayed out to clearly indicate they are inactive when the main auto-approve feature is disabled, providing better visual feedback about which settings are actually in effect.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the Cline auto-approve settings (above the text prompt input)
2. Uncheck "Enable auto-approve" (if it's currently checked)
3. Observe that all other auto-approval options (Toggle all, Read project files, Read all files, Edit project files, Execute safe commands, Use the browser, Use MCP servers) remain visually enabled and appear clickable

### Relevant API REQUEST output

```shell
N/A
```

### Provider/Model

anthropic / claude-sonnet-4-20250514

### Operating System

linux 6.11.0-25-generic

### System Info

VSCode: 1.100.2, Node.js: v20.19.0, Architecture: x64

### Cline Version

3.17.0

### Additional context

This is a UX improvement suggestion to make the interface more intuitive. When the main "Enable auto-approve" option is disabled, users would benefit from visual feedback showing that the sub-options are not active. The developer team can decide whether the grayed-out options should remain clickable (allowing users to pre-configure settings) or be completely disabled.

[Created/submitted by AI: Cline v3, Claude Sonnet 4]

issueDTO.title: Remove unused methods from Google_Proxy class
issueDTO.description:
## Feature Description

Remove unused functionality from the Google_Proxy class to improve code maintainability and reduce technical debt. After analyzing the codebase, the `are_site_fields_synced` method appears to be unused in production code and is only referenced in test files. Additionally, the `fetch_site_fields` method is only used internally by the unused `are_site_fields_synced` method, making it a candidate for removal as well.

This cleanup will streamline the Google_Proxy class by removing dead code that is no longer needed, reducing the maintenance burden and potential confusion for developers working with the authentication system.

---------------

_Do not alter or remove anything below. The following sections will be managed by moderators only._

## Acceptance criteria

* The `are_site_fields_synced` method is removed from the Google_Proxy class in `includes/Core/Authentication/Google_Proxy.php:384-398`
* The `fetch_site_fields` method is removed from the Google_Proxy class in `includes/Core/Authentication/Google_Proxy.php:371-373` (since it's only used by the removed method)
* All related test files are updated to remove references to these methods
* No production code functionality is affected by these removals
* Code documentation is updated if necessary

## Implementation Brief

* [ ] Remove the `are_site_fields_synced` method from the Google_Proxy class ([lines 384-398](https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/ac30b01bcedabc17e77ba957a2dbc4ccea5433ed/includes/Core/Authentication/Google_Proxy.php#L384-L398))
* [ ] Remove the `fetch_site_fields` method from the Google_Proxy class ([lines 371-373](https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/ac30b01bcedabc17e77ba957a2dbc4ccea5433ed/includes/Core/Authentication/Google_Proxy.php#L371-L373)) since it's only used by the method being removed
* [ ] Verify that all authentication flows continue to work properly after removal

### Test Coverage

* [ ] Remove the `test_fetch_site_fields` test method from Google_ProxyTest ([lines 154-190](https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/ac30b01bcedabc17e77ba957a2dbc4ccea5433ed/tests/phpunit/integration/Core/Authentication/Google_ProxyTest.php#L154-L190))
* [ ] Remove the `test_are_site_fields_synced` test method from Google_ProxyTest ([lines 192-220](https://github.com/google/site-kit-wp/blob/ac30b01bcedabc17e77ba957a2dbc4ccea5433ed/tests/phpunit/integration/Core/Authentication/Google_ProxyTest.php#L192-L220))
* [ ] Run full test suite to ensure no unexpected dependencies exist

## QA Brief

* Verify that users can still authenticate with Google services without issues
* Test site setup and registration flows to ensure they work correctly
* Confirm that existing authenticated sites continue to function properly
* Test permissions and setup URLs generation to ensure no regression

## Changelog entry

* Remove unused `are_site_fields_synced` and `fetch_site_fields` methods from Google_Proxy class to reduce technical debt.

issueDTO.title: Abort simulation and raise error if NaN is encountered
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Consider a model with an Isotherm in which a concentration is raised to a fractional power (such as the SMA, the MPML, or the colloidal isotherm) and the column is not initialized with a non-zero salt concentrations. Then during simulations due to numerical reasons said concentration can become negative for short periods of time. This will produce NaN values in the `fluxImpl` and `jacobianImpl` (because we are taking the root of a negative number) and will cause CADET-Core to get stuck, because it keeps re-trying these functions indefinitely. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Check for NaN outputs and terminate the simulation.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
All models could be implemented with linearizations around c=0, this introduces a lot of extra work.
Users could be encouraged to add a time_limit, but this could lead to user frustration.

MRE with working and stuck example:
[SMA_stuck.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19363435/SMA_stuck.zip)

repository.description: The heart of CADET. A modular, fast, and accurate modeling and simulation framework for biotechnology processes.
repository.name: CADET-Core

summary.main: Abort simulation and raise an error if NaN is encountered, to prevent CADET-Core from getting stuck due to re-trying functions indefinitely.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Check for NaN outputs and terminate the simulation.
summary.attemptedFixes: Consider implementing linearizations around c=0, or encouraging users to add a time_limit, but this could lead to user frustration.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to a problem in CADET-Core, specifically in models with Isotherms where concentrations can become negative due to numerical reasons, causing NaN values in the `fluxImpl` and `jacobianImpl`.

issueDTO.title: Invalid HTTP2 headers should be recoverable
issueDTO.description:
## Bug Description

If an invalid HTTP2 header is sent by the server, the client should be able to recover by retrying the operation.  Right now it results in an `uncaughtException`.  See https://github.com/nodejs/undici/discussions/4341 for more details.

## Reproducible By

To reproduce, a mock reply will need to be constructed where an HTTP2 connection to a server gets a response with an HTTP1 header like "http2-settings".  

<!-- A step by step list on how the bug can be reproduced for examination. -->


<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

Ideally a runtime error is thrown, which can be caught in a block where Undici can be directed to retry the operation with a new connection.

## Logs & Screenshots

<!-- If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem, or 
alternatively add your console logs here. -->

Here is an example stack trace from when this occurs:

```javascript
{err":{"type":"TypeError","message":"HTTP/1 Connection specific headers are forbidden: \"http2-settings\"","stack":"TypeError: HTTP/1 Connection specific headers are forbidden: \"http2-settings\"\n    
at mapToHeaders (node:internal/http2/util:651:13)\n    
at ClientHttp2Session.request (node:internal/http2/core:1813:25)\n    
at writeH2 (/.../node_modules/undici/lib/dispatcher/client-h2.js:469:22)\n    
at Object.write (/.../node_modules/undici/lib/dispatcher/client-h2.js:119:14)\n    
at _resume (/.../node_modules/undici/lib/dispatcher/client.js:601:50)\n    
at resume (/.../node_modules/undici/lib/dispatcher/client.js:303:28\n    
at node:internal/process/task_queues:140:7\n    
at AsyncResource.runInAsyncScope (node:async_hooks:206:9)\n    
at AsyncResource.runMicrotask (node:internal/process/task_queues:137:8)","code":"ERR_HTTP2_INVALID_CONNECTION_HEADERS"}
```

## Environment

This was encountered using Node.js 22 on RHEL9.
<!-- This is just your OS and environment information [e.g. Ubuntu 18.04 LTS,
Node v14.14.0] -->

### Additional context

<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->

issueDTO.title: Speed up full_analysis by using implication relations between properties
issueDTO.description:
The package offers the function `abcvoting.properties.full_analysis(profile, committee)` with the following description:
> Test all implemented properties for the given committee.
>
> Returns a dictionary with the following keys: ???pareto???, ???jr???, ???pjr???, ???ejr???, ???ejr+???, ???fjr???, ???priceability???, ???stable-priceability??? and ???core???. The values are True or False, depending on whether this property is satisfied.

https://abcvoting.readthedocs.io/en/latest/properties.html#abcvoting.properties.full_analysis

This function could be sped up by using logical implications between the axioms. For example, begin by checking EJR+. If yes, then no need to check jr/pjr/ejr. Then check JR. If no, then no need to check pjr/ejr/ejr+/fjr/core.

Such implications are already placed in the tests:
https://github.com/martinlackner/abcvoting/blob/2e2c34786f0d62b427cf400fee1a2500413d8f7f/tests/test_properties.py#L359-L368

repository.description: Python implementations of approval-based committee (multi-winner) voting rules
repository.name: abcvoting

summary.main: Speed up the full_analysis function by using implication relations between properties
summary.validationOrRequirement: Use logical implications between axioms to speed up the full_analysis function
summary.otherNotes: The package offers a function to test implemented properties for a given committee, returning a dictionary with various property values. The function could be sped up by using logical implications between axioms, as already implemented in the tests.

issueDTO.title: [Bug] Kimi VL GPU memory usage too high
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [x] 1. I have searched related issues but cannot get the expected help.
- [ ] 2. The bug has not been fixed in the latest version.
- [ ] 3. Please note that if the bug-related issue you submitted lacks corresponding environment info and a minimal reproducible demo, it will be challenging for us to reproduce and resolve the issue, reducing the likelihood of receiving feedback.
- [ ] 4. If the issue you raised is not a bug but a question, please raise a discussion at https://github.com/sgl-project/sglang/discussions/new/choose Otherwise, it will be closed.
- [ ] 5. Please use English, otherwise it will be closed.

### Describe the bug

The GPU memory usage when serving Kimi VL is too high.

### Reproduction

1. First monitor GPU memory usage using `nvitop`
2. Launch server with `python -m sglang.launch_server --model-path moonshotai/Kimi-VL-A3B-Thinking-2506 --trust-remote-code --reasoning-parser kimi --mem-fraction-static 0.5`
The usage should be around 50%.
3. Run `python benchmark/mmmu/bench_sglang.py --port 30000 --concurrency 8` in sglang.
4. Continue monitoring the memory usage, it would up to 98%, and sometimes cause OOM

### Environment

comments: Hi I will take a look at this
We need help with this issue, and it  seems caused by the Kimi ViT, as described in #8008 .
Sorry I was on boarding with my internship. I will check today.
I did a quick check. I think the reason is sdpa requires a large space for activation.

> I did a quick check. I think the reason is sdpa requires a large space for activation.

Thanks! But I think other models also use spda for vision attention, but the behaviour is only observed by kimi vl. May you have a deeper investigation? btw, all the best with your internship :)

# Reason
I spent some time today and I guess I found the answer. In other MLLM models for example, qwen2.5 VL, they use the sdpa attention in vision.py where the q k v's shapes have length four `[batch_size, seq_len, num_heads, head_dim]` while in kimi_vl their shapes have length three `[seq_len, num_heads, head_dim]` and this leads to huge memory consumption difference. 

I vefified this with this change. I changed the code calling the attention in both `vision.py` and `kimi_vl_moonvit.py` from 
```python
    attn_output = F.scaled_dot_product_attention(q, k, v, attention_mask, dropout_p=0.0)
```
to
```python
            print(q.shape, k.shape, v.shape, attention_mask.shape)
            torch.cuda.empty_cache()
            torch.cuda.reset_peak_memory_stats()
            torch.cuda.synchronize()
            before = torch.cuda.memory_allocated()
            output = F.scaled_dot_product_attention(
                q,
                k,
                v,
                attn_mask=attention_mask,
                dropout_p=self.dropout,
                is_causal=False,
            )
            torch.cuda.synchronize()
            after = torch.cuda.memory_allocated()
            peak = torch.cuda.max_memory_allocated()

            intermediate = peak - max(before, after)
            print(f"Intermediate peak memory: {intermediate / 1024 / 1024:.2f} MB")
```
to get the peak memory consumption.
For the same request whose id is `validation_Psychology_16` I got this result from kimi VL:
```
torch.Size([16, 5848, 72]) torch.Size([16, 5848, 72]) torch.Size([16, 5848, 72]) torch.Size([1, 5848, 5848])
Intermediate peak memory: 4855.24 MB
```
and this result from qwen2.5 VL:
```
torch.Size([1, 16, 5676, 80]) torch.Size([1, 16, 5676, 80]) torch.Size([1, 16, 5676, 80]) torch.Size([1, 5676, 5676])
Intermediate peak memory: 109.86 MB
```
Once I add
```python
q.unsqueeze(0)
k.unsqueeze(0)
v.unsqueeze(0)
```
to kimi VL, the memory consumption drops to `66.00 MB`

**I guess this can be bug for torch. WDYT?**

# Fix
**One quick fix** could be add the unsqueeze to qkv and squeeze to attn_output in kimi VL. The problem is numeric stability. I wrote the very simple following script to test the memory consumption and numeric difference:
```python
import torch
import torch.nn.functional as F

if __name__ == "__main__":
    q = torch.randn(16, 5848, 72, device="cuda", dtype=torch.bfloat16)
    k = torch.randn(16, 5848, 72, device="cuda", dtype=torch.bfloat16)
    v = torch.randn(16, 5848, 72, device="cuda", dtype=torch.bfloat16)
    q_cu_seqlens = torch.tensor([0, 5848], device="cuda", dtype=torch.int32)
    seq_length = 5848
    attention_mask = torch.zeros(
        [1, seq_length, seq_length], device=q.device, dtype=torch.bool
    )
    for i in range(1, len(q_cu_seqlens)):
        attention_mask[
            ...,
            q_cu_seqlens[i - 1] : q_cu_seqlens[i],
            q_cu_seqlens[i - 1] : q_cu_seqlens[i],
        ] = True

    # Get the result and peak memory size 
    torch.cuda.empty_cache()
    torch.cuda.reset_peak_memory_stats()
    torch.cuda.synchronize()
    before = torch.cuda.memory_allocated()
    attn_output = F.scaled_dot_product_attention(q, k, v, attention_mask, dropout_p=0.0)
    torch.cuda.synchronize()
    after = torch.cuda.memory_allocated()
    peak = torch.cuda.max_memory_allocated()
    intermediate = peak - max(before, after)
    print(f"Intermediate peak memory: {intermediate / 1024 / 1024:.2f} MB")

    # Get the result and peak memory size when q, k, v are unsqueezed
    torch.cuda.empty_cache()
    torch.cuda.reset_peak_memory_stats()
    torch.cuda.synchronize()
    before = torch.cuda.memory_allocated()
    q = q.unsqueeze(0)
    k = k.unsqueeze(0)
    v = v.unsqueeze(0)
    attn_output_unsqueeze = F.scaled_dot_product_attention(q, k, v, attention_mask, dropout_p=0.0)
    torch.cuda.synchronize()
    after = torch.cuda.memory_allocated()
    peak = torch.cuda.max_memory_allocated()
    intermediate = peak - max(before, after)
    print(f"Intermediate peak memory with unsqueeze: {intermediate / 1024 / 1024:.2f} MB")
    attn_output_unsqueeze = attn_output_unsqueeze.squeeze(0)

    # Compare the largest diff between the two outputs
    diff = torch.abs(attn_output - attn_output_unsqueeze)
    max_diff = torch.max(diff)
    print(f"Max difference between outputs: {max_diff.item()}")
     
```
The numeric diff can be up to 0.001:
```bash
Intermediate peak memory: 4855.24 MB
Intermediate peak memory with unsqueeze: 65.23 MB
Max difference between outputs: 0.0009765625
```
Is a numeric error of 0.001 acceptable?

**The second fix** possible is to convert kimi VL to use the sdpa attention defined in `vision.py` which does not seem to be too different at first look

**The third fix** is possible to raise an issue in PyTorch and fix the memory consumption there.

WDYT?

@PanJason Great! Unsqueeze itself can already be considered a decent plan, you just to need to compare the accuracy before & after.
But I'm more concerned about the fact that even though dims are not in the expected way, the tests still passed. Can you figure out a way preventing this issue from happening?
Hi I compared the accuracy before and after for **one layer** which can be 0.001 and such diff can be aggregated across layers. Is that acceptable?

> Hi I compared the accuracy before and after for **one layer** which can be 0.001 and such diff can be aggregated across layers. Is that acceptable?

Sounds ok, but we should rely on image benchmarks, e.g. mmmu and more from `lmms_eval`
Thanks I will check later this week.
